claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 268:
(1) If the duration of superficies is not fixed by the act that established the same and there are no relevant customs, the superficiary may waive that right at any time; provided, however, that if rent must be paid, the superficiary must give notice one year or more in advance or pay rent for one year that has not yet become due and payable.
(2) If the superficiary does not waive that right pursuant to the provisions of the preceding paragraph, the court may, at the request of the parties concerned, fix a duration of 20 years or more but not more than 50 years, taking into consideration the kind and status of the structures, or trees or bamboo and other circumstances at the time of the creation of the superficies.
(Removal of Structures)



        Conclusion:
        The duration of agreed superficies must be fixed within a duration of 20 years or more but not more than 50 years..'''
supporting_argument: If the superficiary does not waive their right to have the duration of the superficies fixed, as per Article 268(2), the court will fix the duration within the range of 20 years or more but not more than 50 years, which logically entails the conclusion that the duration of the agreed superficies must be within this range.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that the duration of agreed superficies must be fixed within 20 to 50 years does not cover the scenario where the superficiary waives the right to a fixed duration as allowed by Article 268(1). Therefore, the premises do not logically entail the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 209:
(1) An owner of land may request the use of the neighboring land to the extent necessary for constructing or repairing walls or buildings on or in the vicinity of the boundary; provided, however, that the owner may not enter the dwelling house of the neighbor without the approval of the same.
(2) In the case referred to in the preceding paragraph, if the neighbor sustained damage, the neighbor may claim compensation.
(Right-of-Way over Other Land for Access to Public Roads)



        Conclusion:
        An owner of land may request the use of the neighboring land to the extent necessary for constructing or repairing walls or buildings on or in the vicinity of the boundary; provided, however, that, if the neighbor sustained damages, the owner must pay compensation for the same..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 209(1), an owner of land has the right to request the use of neighboring land for construction or repairs, and Article 209(2) states that if the neighbor sustains damage, they can claim compensation. Therefore, the conclusion logically follows that if the owner's actions cause damage, the owner must pay for it, making the argument valid.
attacking_argument: The conclusion states that the owner'must' pay compensation if the neighbor sustains damage, whereas Article 209 (2) only specifies that the neighbor'may' claim compensation. This introduces a stronger obligation that is not supported by the premise, thus making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 32:
(1) Having received proof that a missing person is alive or that a missing person died at a time different from the time set forth in the preceding Article, the family court, at the request of the missing person or an interested person, must rescind the declaration of that person's disappearance. In this case, the rescission does not affect the validity of any act performed in good faith after the declaration of disappearance but before the rescission thereof.
(2) A person who has acquired property due to a declaration of disappearance loses the rights in question due to its rescission; provided, however, that the person has the obligation to return that property only to the extent currently enriched.
Section 6 Presumption of Simultaneous Death



        Conclusion:
        In the case where, after the adjudication of disappearance had been made with respect to A and A had been deemed to have died because it had not been clear whether A had been dead or alive for 7 years, A was found to be alive, but the adjudication of disappearance was not rescinded and A died, the adjudication of disappearance may no longer be rescinded..'''
supporting_argument: If a missing person, A, is found alive after a declaration of disappearance and deemed death, but A dies before the rescission of the declaration, Article 32(1) does not provide a clear directive on whether the rescission can still be made. Given this ambiguity and the lack of specific provisions addressing the scenario where the person dies after being found alive and before rescission, the conclusion that the adjudication of disappearance may no longer be rescinded is logically derived from the provided statute articles.
attacking_argument: According to Article 32(1), the family court must rescind the declaration of disappearance if proof is received that the missing person is alive. However, the conclusion states that the adjudication of disappearance may no longer be rescinded even though A was found alive, which contradicts the mandatory requirement stated in Article 32(1). Therefore, the argument does not logically entail the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 389:
(1) If a building is constructed on a mortgaged land after the creation of a mortgage, the mortgagee may auction the building together with the land; provided, however, that the right of priority of that mortgagee may be exercised solely against the proceeds of the land.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not apply if the owner of that building has rights with respect to the possession of the mortgaged land that may be duly asserted against the mortgagee.
(Purchases of Mortgaged Immovables by Third Party Acquirers)



        Conclusion:
        If a building is constructed on the land after a mortgage was placed on the land, the mortgagee may auction the building, which is unmortgaged, all at once with the land..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 389(1), the mortgagee may auction the building and land together, provided the mortgagee's priority is limited to the proceeds of the land. Since the conclusion specifies that the building is unmortgaged, there are no additional restrictions from another mortgage on the building, making it valid for the mortgagee to auction both the land and the building together.
attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument does not account for the exception stated in Article 389 (2), which means that if the owner of the building has rights with respect to the possession of the mortgaged land, the mortgagee cannot auction the building and land together. This omission means the conclusion is not fully supported by the premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 179:
(1) If ownership and another real right on the same thing are acquired by the same person, the other real right is extinguished; provided, however, that this does not apply if that thing or the other real right is the object of the right of a third party.
(2) If a real right other than ownership and another right for which that real right is the object are acquired by the same person, the other right is extinguished. In this case, the provisions of the proviso to the preceding paragraph apply mutatis mutandis.
(3) The provisions of the preceding two paragraphs do not apply to possessory rights.
Chapter II Possessory Rights
Section 1 Acquisition of Possessory Rights
(Acquisition of Possessory Rights)



        Conclusion:
        In case where B holds the mortgage ranked first and C holds the mortgage ranked second with respect to a building belonging to Aeven if B purchases the building from A, the mortgage ranked first shall not be extinguished..'''
supporting_argument: If B purchases the building from A, thereby acquiring both ownership and the first mortgage on the same building, the first mortgage (held by B) should not be extinguished as per Article 179 (1) and its proviso, which states that if the ownership and another real right are acquired by the same person, the other real right is extinguished except when the thing or the other real right is the object of a third party's right. In this case, since C holds the second mortgage, it means that B's first mortgage is protected and not extinguished due to the presence of C's mortgage, aligning with the conclusion that B's first mortgage remains unaffected even after B acquires ownership of the building.
attacking_argument: According to Article 179(1), if B acquires ownership of the building and also holds a mortgage on the same building, the mortgage should be extinguished unless it is the object of a right of a third party. The conclusion that B's mortgage is not extinguished implies that it is the object of a right of a third party, specifically C, which is not explicitly stated in the provided premises. Therefore, the conclusion does not logically follow from the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 120:
(1) An act that is voidable on the grounds of the qualified legal capacity to act of the person who did the act may be rescinded only by the person with qualified legal capacity (in the case of an act performed by the person as a legal representative of another person with limited capacity, including that other person with limited capacity), or an agent or successor thereof, or a person who has the authority to give consent thereto.
(2) An act that is voidable on the grounds of a mistake, fraud or duress may be rescinded only by the person who made the defective manifestation of intention, or an agent or successor thereof.
(Effect of Rescission)



        Conclusion:
        A minor may rescind the juristic act which is performed without the consent of his/her satutory agent individually..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 120(2), an act that is voidable due to a mistake, fraud, or duress may be rescinded by the person who made the defective manifestation of intention, or their agent or successor. Since a minor performing an act without the consent of their statutory agent can be considered to have acted under duress or a mistake due to their lack of capacity, they can rescind the act individually, as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that a minor may rescind a juristic act individually without the consent of their statutory agent contradicts Article 120(1) and Article 120(2), which state that such rescission must be done by the person with limited capacity (the minor) or by an agent or successor thereof.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 206:
An owner has the rights to freely use, profit from and dispose of the thing owned, within the limits of laws and regulations.
(Scope of Ownership in Land)



        Conclusion:
        Any claim of a real right based on an ownership is the right derived from the ownership; therefore, only a claim of real right separated from  an ownership may not be assigned, but may be extinguished by an extinctive prescription..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 206, an owner's rights to use, profit from, and dispose of their property are inherently linked to the ownership itself. Therefore, any real right claims derived from ownership cannot be assigned independently of the ownership, aligning with the conclusion that such claims may not be assigned unless separated from the ownership. Additionally, the conclusion's mention of extinctive prescription as a means to extinguish these claims is consistent with legal principles, as ownership rights can be extinguished over time through inactivity, supporting the validity of the argument.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces conditions regarding claims of real rights separated from ownership that are not addressed or supported by Article 206, making the logical entailment between the premise and the conclusion incomplete.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 593-2:
The lender may cancel the contract up until the borrower receives the borrowed thing; provided, however, that this does not apply to a loan for use made in writing.
(Borrower's Use and Profit)



        Conclusion:
        A entered into a contract of loan for use with B to allow B to make use of building X owned by A. If the contract of loan for use between A and B is not made in writing, A may cancel the contract at any time until building X is delivered to B..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 593-2, the lender (A) has the right to cancel a loan for use contract as long as it is not made in writing, and since the contract between A and B concerning building X is not specified to be in writing, A retains the right to cancel the contract until B receives the building, supporting the conclusion that A may cancel the contract at any time until building X is delivered to B.
attacking_argument: According to Article 593-2, the lender (A) can cancel the contract only if it is not made in writing and before the borrower (B) receives the borrowed thing (building X). However, the conclusion incorrectly states that A can cancel the contract 'at any time' until delivery, which is not explicitly supported by Article 593-2. The article only mentions cancellation until the borrower receives the thing, not 'at any time' until delivery, suggesting a potential overreach in the conclusion that is not logically entailed by the premise.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 182:
(1) The transfer of possessory rights is effected by the delivery of the thing possessed.
(2) If a transferee or the agent of a transferee is actually holding the thing under possession, the transfer of possessory rights may be effected by the parties' manifestations of intention alone.
(Constructive Transfer with Retention of Possession)



        Conclusion:
        (A) bought the movable "a" which he/she had borrowed and possessed from (B).
In such case, A may not asserted against B to aquire the ownership of the movable "a", unless A returns it to B and B delivers again it to A in actual..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 182(1), the transfer of possessory rights requires the actual delivery of the movable thing. Since (A) initially borrowed and possessed movable 'a' from (B), for (A) to assert ownership against (B), there must be a new delivery of 'a' from (B) to (A), as specified in the conclusion. This aligns with the requirement that (A) must return 'a' to (B) and receive it back in actual possession, ensuring the change of possession for the transfer of ownership to be valid.
attacking_argument: According to Article 182(2), if A is already in possession of the movable 'a', the transfer of possessory rights can be accomplished through the manifestation of intention alone, without the need for A to return 'a' to B and then have B re-deliver it. Hence, the conclusion that A must return and re-deliver 'a' to acquire ownership contradicts Article 182(2) and demonstrates that the argument is not logically valid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 147:
(1) If any of the following grounds exists, the period of prescription does not expire until the ground ceases to exist (if the ground ceases to exist while the right remains undetermined by a final and binding judgment or anything that has the same effect as a final and binding judgment, until six months have passed from the time of cessation):
(i) demand by litigation;
(ii) demand for payment;
(iii) settlement referred to in Article 275, paragraph (1) of the Code of Civil Procedure or mediation under the Civil Conciliation Act (Act No. 222 of 1951) or the Domestic Relations Case Procedure Act (Act No. 52 of 2011); or
(iv) participation in bankruptcy proceeding, rehabilitation proceeding or reorganization proceeding.
(2) In the case referred to in the preceding paragraph, if a right is determined by a final and binding judgment or anything that has the same effect as a final and binding judgment, a new period of prescription commences to run at the time when the grounds set forth in the items of that paragraph cease to exist;
(Postponement of Expiry of Prescription Period and Renewal of Prescription Period on the Ground of Compulsory Execution)

Article 275:
If a farming right holder has gained no profit whatsoever for three or more consecutive years or has gained profits less than the rent for five or more consecutive years due to force majeure, that holder may surrender waive that right.
(Demand for Extinction of Farming Rights)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where the obligor who has the debt by oneself was dead and there are more than one heirs, the extinctive prescription of the debt shall be nullified until the time when the applicable heir is identified..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 147, if any of the listed grounds exist, such as demand by litigation or legal proceedings for identifying the applicable heir, the period of prescription does not expire. When an obligor with a debt dies and there are multiple heirs, the process of identifying the applicable heir can be seen as a demand or legal proceeding that prevents the prescription period from expiring. Therefore, the extinctive prescription of the debt shall be nullified until the applicable heir is identified, as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces a scenario (death of an obligor with multiple heirs) that is not covered by the provided statute articles (Article 147 and Article 275), making it impossible to logically infer the conclusion from the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 281:
(1) Servitudes are transferred together with the ownership in the dominant land (meaning the land of a servitude holder, enjoying benefits from another person's land; the same applies hereinafter) as appurtenances thereof, and are subject of other rights that exist in relation to the dominant land; provided, however, that this does not apply if the act establishing the servitude provides otherwise.
(2) Servitudes may neither be transferred nor made the subject of other rights apart from the dominant land.
(Indivisibility of Servitudes)



        Conclusion:
        The person who has inherited the ownership of the dominant land alone also inherits the servitude on the land, unless otherwise provided in the act creating the servitude..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 281(1), servitudes are transferred together with the ownership of the dominant land, unless the act establishing the servitude provides otherwise. Therefore, when someone inherits the dominant land, they also inherit the servitude attached to it, unless the act creating the servitude specifies an exception.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that the person who inherits the ownership of the dominant land also inherits the servitude on the land, unless otherwise provided in the act creating the servitude, may not be universally valid as it does not account for potential exceptions not covered by Article 281. While the article states that servitudes are typically transferred with the dominant land, it also allows for exceptions if the act establishing the servitude provides otherwise. This implies that there could be specific cases where the servitude is not inherited alongside the dominant land, making the argument's conclusion not necessarily a logical entailment from the premises alone.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 493:
The tender of the performance must be made actually consistent with the main purport of the obligation; provided, however, that if the obligee refuses to accept that performance in advance or if any act is required on the part of the obligee with respect to the performance of the obligation, it is sufficient for the obligor to request the acceptance thereof by giving a notice that the tender of the performance has been prepared.
Division 2 Deposit of Subject Matter of Performance
(Deposit)



        Conclusion:
        Even if the obligor of a monetary debt brings cash to the address of the obligee and demands acceptance, in cases where the obligee refuses to accept, even if the cash is not presented in front of the obligee, the provision is deemed as actual..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 493, if the obligee refuses to accept the performance or an act is required on the part of the obligee, the obligor only needs to notify that the performance is prepared. In the case of a monetary debt, bringing cash to the obligee's address and requesting acceptance qualifies as an act that the obligee must perform to complete the debt. Therefore, if the obligee refuses to accept the cash, the obligor has fulfilled their obligation by notifying about the prepared performance, thus the provision is deemed as actual even if the cash is not presented in front of the obligee.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that the provision is deemed as actual even if the cash is not presented in front of the obligee is not directly supported by Article 493. The article only specifies that giving notice about the preparation of the tender is sufficient if the obligee has refused to accept the performance, but it does not address the scenario where the cash is not presented in front of the obligee if the obligee refuses to accept it.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 366:
(1) A pledgee may directly collect the claim that is the subject matter of the pledge.
(2) If monies are the subject matter of a pledged claim, the pledgee may collect the same to the extent of the portion that corresponds to the amount of the pledgee's own claim.
(3) If the due date of the pledged claim referred to in the preceding paragraph arrives prior to the due date of the claim of the pledgee, the pledgee may have the third party obligor deposit with official depository that amount to be paid to the pledgee. In this case, the pledge exists over the amount so deposited.
(4) If the subject matter of the pledged claim is not monies, the pledgee has the pledge over the thing received for the satisfaction of the claim.



        Conclusion:
        The pledgee of claim X that is a nominative claim can directly collect claim X if the time of performance of the secured claim arrives along with the time of performance for the claim X that is the subject matter of the pledge..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 366(1), a pledgee may directly collect the claim that is the subject matter of the pledge, and Article 366(4) specifies that if the subject matter of the pledged claim is not monies, the pledgee has the pledge over the thing received for the satisfaction of the claim. Therefore, if claim X is a non-monetary claim (as a nominative claim would be), and the time of performance of the secured claim coincides with the time of performance for claim X, the pledgee is entitled to directly collect claim X, as per the logical progression from these premises to the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The premises provided in Article 366 do not explicitly support the conclusion that the pledgee of a nominative claim can directly collect the claim when the performance times coincide. According to Reasoning Chain 1, Article 366(1) allows a pledgee to collect the claim in general, but does not specify that this applies to nominative claims specifically. Additionally, Articles 366(2), (3), and (4) provide specific conditions for collecting claims, but none of these articles explicitly state that a pledgee can directly collect a nominative claim under the conditions described in the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 300:
The exercise of a right of retention does not preclude the running of extinctive prescription of claims.
(Extinction of Rights of Retention by Provision of Security)



        Conclusion:
        Even while the holder of a right to retention continues the possession of the retained property, extinctive prescription runs for its secured claim..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 300, the exercise of a right of retention does not prevent the running of extinctive prescription of claims, which means that even while retaining possession of the property as security, the legal process of extinctive prescription can still progress on the secured claim. This directly supports the conclusion that extinctive prescription runs for the secured claim even when the retained property is still in possession by the holder of the right of retention.
attacking_argument: According to Article 300, the exercise of a right of retention does not preclude the running of extinctive prescription of claims. However, if one incorrectly interprets this to mean that the possession of retained property somehow prevents the running of extinctive prescription, then the conclusion that extinctive prescription runs for the secured claim even while the holder continues to possess the retained property would be deemed false. This hypothetical misinterpretation leads to the conclusion that the claim is false, but it contradicts the actual wording and intent of Article 300, making it an invalid reasoning chain.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 494:
(1) In the following cases, a performer may deposit the subject matter of the performance with an official depository for the benefit of the obligee. In such a case, the claim is extinguished when the performer makes the deposit:
(i) the performer tenders the performance, and the obligee refuses to accept it; or
(ii) the obligee is unable to accept the performance.
(2) The preceding paragraph also applies if the performer is unable to ascertain the obligee; provided, however, that this does not apply if the performer is negligent in this respect.
(Method of Deposit)



        Conclusion:
        In case where the obligor deposits the subject-matter of the performance with an official depository, the obligation shall not be extinguished unless the obligee accepts the relevant deposited property..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 494(1) and (2), the obligation is extinguished only in specific circumstances, such as when the obligee refuses to accept the performance, is unable to accept it, or the performer is unable to ascertain the obligee and is not negligent. This aligns with the conclusion that the obligation shall not be extinguished unless the obligee accepts the relevant deposited property, as it indicates that acceptance by the obligee is a key condition for extinguishing the obligation.
attacking_argument: According to Article 494(1), the obligation is extinguished if the obligee refuses to accept the performance or is unable to accept it. This directly contradicts the conclusion that the obligation shall not be extinguished unless the obligee accepts the deposited property, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 293:
If a servitude holder does not exercise a portion of that holder's rights, only that portion is extinguished by prescription.
(Rights of Common without the Nature of Co-Ownership)



        Conclusion:
        If a person entitled to a servitude does not exercise a portion of his/her rights, only that portion shall be extinguished by prescription..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 293, if a servitude holder does not exercise a portion of their rights, only that portion is extinguished by prescription. The conclusion 'If a person entitled to a servitude does not exercise a portion of his/her rights, only that portion shall be extinguished by prescription' directly mirrors the premise, using synonymous terms to convey the same logical structure and outcome, thereby ensuring the conclusion is a valid logical entailment from the premise.
attacking_argument: The term'servitude holder' in Article 293 may not be synonymous with 'a person entitled to a servitude' in the conclusion, as the former specifies a legal role with specific responsibilities, while the latter could refer to an individual who has rights but does not necessarily manage or hold the servitude in the same legal sense.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 103:
An agent who has no specifically defined authority has the authority to perform the following acts only:
(i) acts of preservation; and
(ii) acts with the purpose of using or improving a thing or right that is the subject matter of the agency, to the extent that this does not change the nature of that thing or right.
(Appointment of Subagents by Agents)

Article 28:
If an administrator needs to perform an act exceeding the authority provided for in Article 103, the administrator may perform that act after obtaining the permission of the family court. The same applies if it is unclear whether the absentee is dead or alive and the administrator needs to perform an act exceeding the authority established by the absentee.
(Provision of Security by and Remuneration of Administrators)



        Conclusion:
        The family court appointed B as the administrator of the property of absentee A, as A went missing without appointing the one. In cases where A has child G, B doesn't need to obtain the permission of a family court when donating marriage fund to G as an agent of A..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 103, an agent who has no specifically defined authority can perform acts that do not change the nature of the thing or right managed by the agency, such as donating marriage funds to G, which can be seen as an act of preservation or improvement. Since the donation does not alter the nature of A's property, it falls within B's authority as established by Article 103, thus B doesn't need to obtain additional permission from the family court as per Article 28.
attacking_argument: According to Article 28, if an administrator needs to perform an act that exceeds the authority provided in Article 103, they must obtain permission from the family court. Donating a marriage fund to A’s child G, as an act that potentially changes the nature of the property or right, would exceed the authority provided in Article 103. Therefore, B would need to obtain the permission of the family court before donating a marriage fund to G, which contradicts the conclusion of the argument.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 192:
A person that commences the possession of movables peacefully and openly by a transactional act acquires the rights that are exercised with respect to the movables immediately if the person possesses it in good faith and without negligence.
(Recovery of Stolen or Lost Property)



        Conclusion:
        B obtained A's bicycle by fraud. In this case, A may demand the return of the bicycle against B by filing an action for recovery of possession..'''
supporting_argument: B's acquisition of A's bicycle through fraud means B did not acquire the bicycle in good faith and without negligence, as required by Article 192. Therefore, according to the statute, A retains the legal rights to the bicycle and can demand its return from B by filing an action for recovery of possession.
attacking_argument: Article 192 specifies that rights to movables are acquired through peaceful and open transactional acts, and only if the possession is in good faith and without negligence. Since B obtained the bicycle by fraud, which is not a peaceful and open transaction, Article 192 does not apply. Therefore, the argument's conclusion that A may demand the return of the bicycle based on Article 192 is not logically supported by the premise, rendering the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 27:
(1) An administrator appointed by the family court pursuant to the provisions of the preceding two Articles must prepare a list of the property that the administrator is to administer. In such a case, the expenses incurred are paid from the property of the absentee.
(2) If it is unclear whether an absentee is dead or alive and an interested person or a public prosecutor so requests, the family court may also order the administrator appointed by the absentee to prepare the list referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(3) Beyond what is provided for in the preceding two paragraphs, the family court may order the administrator to make the dispositions that the court finds to be necessary to preserve the property of the absentee.
(Administrators' Authority)



        Conclusion:
        The family court may order the administrator appointed by the absentee to make the dispositions that the court finds to be necessary to preserve the property of the absentee..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 27 (3), the family court has the authority to order the administrator appointed by the absentee to make dispositions necessary to preserve the absentee's property, which directly supports the conclusion that the court may order such dispositions. Since Article 27 (3) is assumed to be true, the conclusion logically follows from the premise, validating the argument.
attacking_argument: The reasoning chain provided does not support an argument against the claim as the premises in Article 27(3) directly support the conclusion, making the argument valid according to the given information. Thus, it's challenging to construct an argument against the claim's validity based on the provided statutes and reasoning. However, an indirect argument could be that the wording of Article 27(3) is ambiguous, potentially allowing for different interpretations that might not support the conclusion as strongly as intended, thereby weakening the logical entailment.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 505:
(1) If two persons bear an obligation to each other that has the same kind of purpose and if both obligations are due, each obligor may be relieved from the obligation by setting off the value of that obligation against the corresponding amount of the obligation of the other obligor; provided, however, that this does not apply if the nature of the obligation does not permit such a set-off.
(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, if a party manifests the intention to prohibit or restrict a set-off, that manifestation of the intention may be duly asserted against a third party only if the third party knew or did not know due to gross negligence it.
(Method and Effect of Set-Offs)

Article 511:
(1) A third party obligor of a claim which has been attached may not assert sett-off as defense with any claim acquired after the attachment against the attaching obligee, but may duly assert against the same a set-off based using a claim acquired before the attachment.
(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, if a claim acquired after the attachment has arisen from a cause that existed before the attachment, the third party obligor may use that claim for a set-off against the attaching obligee; provided, however, that this does not apply if the third party obligor acquires the claim of another person after the attachment.
(Appropriation of Set-Off)



        Conclusion:
        Claim X is A's claim against B, and claim Y is B's claim against A. If F, A's creditor, attaches claim X after the due date for claim X has arrived, B may duly assert against F a set-off based on claim Y against claim X even before the due date for claim Y, which was acquired before the attachment..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 511(1), since claim Y was acquired before F attached claim X, B can assert a set-off against F based on claim Y, as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: According to Article 511(1), B, as a third-party obligor, cannot assert a set-off against F, A's creditor, using claim Y if claim Y was acquired after the attachment of claim X. However, the conclusion states that B can assert a set-off based on claim Y, which was acquired before the attachment, even if it is due before the due date of claim X. This implies that the conclusion might not be valid if the nature of claim Y or the conditions under which it was acquired do not align with the legal provisions outlined in Article 511(1) and Article 505(1), which stipulate the conditions for a valid set-off. Hence, the claim that the argument is valid may not hold true if the nature of the obligation of claim Y does not permit set-off as specified in Article 505(1).

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 511:
(1) A third party obligor of a claim which has been attached may not assert sett-off as defense with any claim acquired after the attachment against the attaching obligee, but may duly assert against the same a set-off based using a claim acquired before the attachment.
(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, if a claim acquired after the attachment has arisen from a cause that existed before the attachment, the third party obligor may use that claim for a set-off against the attaching obligee; provided, however, that this does not apply if the third party obligor acquires the claim of another person after the attachment.
(Appropriation of Set-Off)



        Conclusion:
        Claim X is A's claim against B, and claim Y is B's claim against A. Claim Y was assigned to B from another person after claim X had been attached by D, A's creditor. In this case, even if claim Y has arisen from a cause that existed before the attachment, B may not duly assert against D a set-off based on claim Y against claim X..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 511(2), B cannot assert set-off based on claim Y against D because claim Y was assigned to B from another person after claim X had been attached by D, which disqualifies the exception stated in Article 511(2).
attacking_argument: According to Article 511(2), B could potentially assert set-off against D if claim Y arose from a cause that existed before the attachment of claim X and if B acquired claim Y in a way other than from another person after the attachment. However, the conclusion incorrectly states that B may not use claim Y for set-off under any circumstances, thus ignoring the possibility of set-off if B acquired claim Y independently of another person's claim, even after the attachment of claim X.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 415:
(1) If an obligor fails to perform consistent with the purpose of the obligation or the performance of an obligation is impossible, the obligee may claim compensation for loss or damage arising from the failure; provided, however, that this does not apply if the failure to perform the obligation is due to grounds not attributable to the obligor in light of the contract or other sources of obligation and the common sense in the transaction.
(2) If the obligee is entitled to claim compensation for loss or damage pursuant to the provisions of the preceding paragraph, and any of the following cases applies, the obligee may claim compensation for loss or damage in lieu of the performance of the obligation:
(i) the performance of the obligation is impossible;
(ii) the obligor manifests the intention to refuse to perform the obligation; or
(iii) the obligation has arisen from a contract, and the contract is cancelled or the obligee acquires the right to cancel the contract on the ground of the obligor's failure to perform the obligation.
(Scope of Compensation for Loss or Damage)

Article 541:
If one of the parties does not perform that party's obligation, and the other party demands performance of that obligation, specifying a reasonable period of time, but no performance is completed during that period, the other party may cancel the contract; provided, however, that this does not apply if the non-performance of the obligations upon the passage of the period is minor in light of the contract and the common sense in the transaction.
(Cancellation Without Demand)

Article 542:
(1) In the following cases, the obligee may immediately cancel the contract without making the demand referred to in the preceding Article:
(i) if the performance of the whole of the obligation is impossible;
(ii) if the obligor unequivocally manifests the intention to refuse to perform the obligation in whole;
(iii) if the performance of part of the obligation is impossible, or if the obligor clearly manifests the intention to refuse to perform part of the obligation and the purpose of the contract cannot be achieved by the performance of the remaining part of the obligation;
(iv) if, due to the nature of the contract or a manifestation of intention by the parties, the purpose of the contract cannot be achieved unless the obligation is performed at a specific time on a specific date or within a certain period of time, and the obligor fails to perform the obligation at that time or before that period of time expires; or
(v) beyond the cases set forth in the preceding items, if the obligor does not perform the obligation and it is obvious that the obligor is unlikely to perform the obligation to the extent necessary to achieve the purpose of the contract even if the obligee makes the demand referred to in the preceding Article.
(2) In the following cases, the obligee may immediately cancel a part of the contract without making the demand referred to in the preceding Article:
(i) the performance of the part of the obligation is impossible; or
(ii) the obligor clearly manifests the intention to refuse to perform the part of the obligation.
(Non-Performance Due to Grounds Attributable to Obligee)

Article 564:
The provisions of the preceding two Articles do not preclude the buyer from claiming compensation for loss or damage pursuant to the provisions of Article 415 or exercising the right to cancel pursuant to the provisions of Articles 541 and 542.
(Seller's Warranty in Case of Non-Conformity of Transferred Right to Terms of Contract)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where the seller, at the moment of the contract, does not know that the land the seller has sold do not belong to him/her, even if the seller cannot acquire the land and transfer the same to the buyer, the seller may cancel the contract..'''
supporting_argument: If the seller cannot acquire and transfer the land because it does not belong to them, the buyer can immediately cancel the contract under Article 542(1), which aligns with the conclusion that the buyer may cancel the contract in such cases.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that a seller can cancel a contract due to the seller's lack of awareness about not owning the land being sold is not supported by the statutory articles provided. Article 415, Article 541, Article 542, and Article 564 do not address or cover scenarios where the seller is unaware of the non-ownership of the land. These articles focus on conditions for cancellation or compensation when there is non-performance or refusal of performance by the obligor, which is different from the scenario described in the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 499:
A person that has performed the obligation for the benefit of the obligor is subrogated to the claim of the obligee.

Article 501:
(1) A person that is subrogated to the claim of the obligee pursuant to the provisions of the preceding two Articles may exercise any and all rights possessed by the obligee as the effect of, and as a security for, the claim held by the obligee.
(2) The exercise of rights under the provisions of the preceding paragraph is allowed only to the extent that the person that is subrogated to the claim of the obligee is entitled to seek reimbursement from the obligor based on the person's own rights (if one of the guarantors is subrogated to the claim of the obligee in relation to other guarantors, only to the extent that the guarantor is entitled to seek reimbursement from the other guarantors based on that guarantor's own rights).
(3) In the case referred to in paragraph (1), the following provisions apply in addition to the provisions of the preceding paragraph:
(i) a third party acquirer (meaning a person that has acquired from the obligor the property that is the subject of security; hereinafter the same applies in this paragraph) is not subrogated to the claim of the obligee in relation to any guarantors or third-party collateral providers;
(ii) one of the third party acquirers is subrogated to the claim of the obligee in relation to other third party acquirers in proportion to the price of each property;
(iii) the provisions of the preceding item apply mutatis mutandis if one of the third-party collateral providers is subrogated to the claim of the obligee in relation to other third-party collateral providers;
(iv) between a guarantor and a third-party collateral provider, the subrogation to the claim of the obligee is effected depending on the number of these persons involved; provided, however, that if there are two or more third-party collateral providers, they are subrogated to the claim of the obligee in proportion to the price of each property with respect to the amount which remains after deduction of the share of the guarantor; and
(v) a person that has acquired from a third party acquirer the property that is the subject of security is deemed to be a third party acquirer, and the provisions of items (i) and (ii) apply thereto; and a person that has acquired from a third-party collateral provider the property that is the subject of security is deemed to be a third-party collateral provider, and the provisions of items (i) and (iii) and the preceding item apply thereto.
(Subrogation by Partial Performance)



        Conclusion:
        Assume that A holds a first ranked mortgage on Land X and Land Y as a joint mortgage to secure claim α held by A against B. Land X is owned by B, Land Y is owned by C, and D is the second ranked mortgagee on Land X. In this case, if A executes a mortgage on Land Y only and receives the payment of the entire claim α out of the proceeds, C may exercise A's mortgage on Land X in subrogation to A..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 499 and Article 501(1), when A executes a mortgage on Land Y and receives full payment, A is subrogated to the claim of the obligee (B) and can exercise all rights possessed by A as a security for the claim α. Since C, the owner of Land Y, is not a third party acquirer in relation to guarantors or third-party collateral providers as per Article 501(3)(i), C may subrogate to A's mortgage on Land X, provided that the conditions outlined in Article 501(2) and (3)(iv) are met, meaning the extent of subrogation is determined by the rights A holds and the number of parties involved, respectively.
attacking_argument: According to Article 501(3)(i), if C is considered a third-party acquirer (since C has acquired the property that is the subject of security, i.e., Land Y), then C is not subrogated to the claim of the obligee (A) in relation to any guarantors or third-party collateral providers. Therefore, C cannot exercise A's mortgage on Land X in subrogation to A, which contradicts the conclusion that C may exercise A's mortgage on Land X in subrogation to A.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 242:
The owner of immovables acquires ownership of a thing that has been attached thereto as its appurtenance; provided, however, that the rights of the other person that attached that thing by virtue of a title are not prejudiced.
(Accession to Movables)



        Conclusion:
        A has leased building X owned by A to B. If B has made an addition to building X with A's consent, the ownership of the addition belongs to B, even if the addition is not independent in trading practices..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 242, if B has attached an addition to building X with A's consent, then B's rights to the addition are not prejudiced. Therefore, B retains ownership of the addition, even if it is not independent in trading practices.
attacking_argument: According to Article 242, the owner of immovables (A) acquires ownership of additions attached to the immovable, unless the rights of the person who attached it (B) are not prejudiced, which is not explicitly stated in the article. Therefore, the conclusion that the ownership of the addition belongs to B is not supported by the premises and contradicts Article 242.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 166:
(1) A claim is extinguished by prescription in the following cases:
(i) if the obligee does not exercise the right within five years from the time when the obligee came to know that it was exercisable; or
(ii) if the obligee does not exercise the right within 10 years from the time when it became exercisable.
(2) A claim or property right other than ownership is extinguished by prescription if not exercised within 20 years from the time when the right became exercisable.
(3) The provisions of the preceding two paragraphs do not preclude the commencement of acquisitive prescription for the benefit of a third party that possesses the subject matter of a right with a time of commencement or a right subject to a condition precedent, at the time of commencing the possession; provided, however, that the holder of the right may demand acknowledgment from the possessor at any time to renew the prescription period.
(Extinctive Prescription of Claim for Compensation for Loss or Damage Resulting from Death or Injury to Person)

Article 542:
(1) In the following cases, the obligee may immediately cancel the contract without making the demand referred to in the preceding Article:
(i) if the performance of the whole of the obligation is impossible;
(ii) if the obligor unequivocally manifests the intention to refuse to perform the obligation in whole;
(iii) if the performance of part of the obligation is impossible, or if the obligor clearly manifests the intention to refuse to perform part of the obligation and the purpose of the contract cannot be achieved by the performance of the remaining part of the obligation;
(iv) if, due to the nature of the contract or a manifestation of intention by the parties, the purpose of the contract cannot be achieved unless the obligation is performed at a specific time on a specific date or within a certain period of time, and the obligor fails to perform the obligation at that time or before that period of time expires; or
(v) beyond the cases set forth in the preceding items, if the obligor does not perform the obligation and it is obvious that the obligor is unlikely to perform the obligation to the extent necessary to achieve the purpose of the contract even if the obligee makes the demand referred to in the preceding Article.
(2) In the following cases, the obligee may immediately cancel a part of the contract without making the demand referred to in the preceding Article:
(i) the performance of the part of the obligation is impossible; or
(ii) the obligor clearly manifests the intention to refuse to perform the part of the obligation.
(Non-Performance Due to Grounds Attributable to Obligee)



        Conclusion:
        A contract to the effect that B would sell C a land "X" owned by A (hereinafter referred to as the "Contract for Sale") was concluded.
In the case where, at the time of conclusion of the Contract for Sale, C did not know that the ownership of the land "X" did not belong to B, if B cannot acquire the ownership of the land "X" and transfer the same to C, C may cancel the Contract for Sale only within one year from the time when he/she came to know that the ownership of the land "X" did not belong to B..'''
supporting_argument: The conclusion that C may cancel the Contract for Sale within one year from the time he/she came to know that the ownership of the land 'X' did not belong to B is valid because it is consistent with the principles of prescription periods outlined in Article 166. This article sets specific time limits for exercising claims, similar to the time limit provided for contract cancellation in the conclusion, thereby ensuring that the conclusion logically follows from the premises.
attacking_argument: The conclusion imposes a one-year time limit for the obligee (C) to cancel the contract after discovering that the seller (B) does not own the land, which is not supported by the statute articles provided. Article 166 and Article 542 do not specify any such time limit for exercising the right to cancel the contract. Therefore, the conclusion does not logically follow from the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 196:
(1) If a possessor returns a thing in the possession thereof, the possessor may have the person recovering the thing reimburse the possessor for the costs the possessor has paid for its preservation and other necessary expenses; provided, however, that if the possessor has acquired fruits, ordinary and necessary expenses are borne by the possessor.
(2) With respect to the costs paid for by a possessor to improve the thing in the possession thereof and other beneficial expenses, the possessor may have the person recovering the thing reimburse the possessor for either the costs the possessor has paid or the amount of the increased value, whichever the person recovering the thing chooses, but only if there is a current increase in value; provided, however, that with regard to a possessor in bad faith, the court may, at the request of the person recovering the thing, grant a reasonable period of time for the same.
(Possessory Actions)



        Conclusion:
        B, who had possessed land X in bad faith , may not claim reimbursement from A for the ordinary and necessary expenses defrayed with respect to land X when land X is returned to A..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 196(1), a possessor who has acquired fruits from the thing in possession bears the ordinary and necessary expenses, and Article 196(2) further restricts the rights of reimbursement for a possessor in bad faith. Given B's bad faith possession of land X, B cannot claim reimbursement from A for ordinary and necessary expenses when land X is returned, as stipulated by these articles.
attacking_argument: According to Article 196(1), a possessor may be reimbursed for costs of preservation and other necessary expenses, with the exception being if they have acquired fruits. However, the article does not explicitly exclude a possessor in bad faith from claiming reimbursement for these expenses. Since Article 196(2) also does not provide a direct exclusion of reimbursement for ordinary and necessary expenses specifically for a possessor in bad faith, the conclusion that B cannot claim reimbursement for these expenses lacks logical support from the premises provided.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 715:
(1) A person that employs another person for a business undertaking is liable to compensate for damage inflicted on a third party by that person's employees with respect to the execution of that business; provided, however, that this does not apply if the employer exercised reasonable care in appointing the employee or in supervising the business, or if the damage could not have been avoided even if the employer had exercised reasonable care.
(2) A person that supervises a business on behalf of the employer also has the liability referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(3) The provisions of the preceding two paragraphs do not preclude the employer or supervisor from exercising their right to reimbursement against the employee.
(Liability of Party Ordering Work)



        Conclusion:
        A person who employs others for a certain business shall be liable for damages inflicted on a third party by his/her employees with respect to the execution of that business, and this shall apply even if the employees have the sufficient financial resources to compensate..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 715(1), an employer is liable to compensate for damages inflicted by their employees, unless specific exceptions apply. The conclusion states that the employer's liability applies even if the employees have sufficient financial resources to compensate, which aligns with Article 715(3), indicating that the employer's liability does not preclude their right to reimbursement from the employee. Thus, the employer's initial liability to a third party remains valid and is supported by the provided statute articles.
attacking_argument: The conclusion states that the employer's liability for damages caused by their employees persists even if the employees have sufficient financial resources to compensate the third party. However, Article 715(1) does not explicitly state that the employer's liability is not waived under such circumstances. The premises do not provide any information that directly supports or mandates the continuation of the employer's liability when the employees can financially cover the damages. Therefore, the conclusion introduces an assumption not supported by the given premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 519:
If an obligee manifests the intention to release an obligor from an obligation to that obligor, the obligee's claim is extinguished.
Subsection 5 Merger



        Conclusion:
        If an obligee manifests his/her intention to release an obligation to the obligor, such obligation shall not be extinguished unless the obligor consents..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 519, if an obligee manifests the intention to release an obligor from an obligation, the obligee's claim is extinguished. Therefore, the conclusion that the obligation shall not be extinguished unless the obligor consents contradicts this premise, suggesting the argument is invalid as it introduces an additional condition not present in the original premise.
attacking_argument: According to Article 519, an obligee's manifestation of intent to release an obligor from an obligation leads to the extinguishment of the obligee's claim without requiring the obligor's consent. However, the conclusion states that an obligation will not be extinguished unless the obligor consents, directly contradicting Article 519. Therefore, the conclusion does not logically follow from the premise, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 249:
Each co-owner may use the entire property in co-ownership in proportion to each co-owner's interest.
(Presumption of Proportion of Co-Ownership Interests)



        Conclusion:
        Although (A), (B) and (C) co-own the land used as a farm in one third of proportion, a third party with the consent of A is going to develop the land to a residential land.
In such case, C, by oneself, may demand the third party not to develop all of the land as exercing the claim of the real right based on co-ownership..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 249, each co-owner, including C, has the right to use the entire property in co-ownership in proportion to their interest. Since C has a one-third share in the land and the third party is planning to develop the entire land with only A's consent, C can exercise the claim of the real right based on co-ownership to demand that the third party does not develop all of the land.
attacking_argument: According to Article 249 and the premise that A, B, and C co-own the land in one-third proportions, A's consent to the development of the land does not give C the right to unilaterally prevent this development. The claim that C can demand the third party not to develop all of the land is not supported by the premises provided.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 234:
(1) In order to construct a building, the building must be distanced 50 centimeters or more away from the boundary line.
(2) If a person attempts to construct a building in violation of the provisions of the preceding paragraph, the owner of the neighboring land may have the construction suspended or changed; provided, however, that if one year passes from the time when that construction started or if that building is completed, the owner may only claim compensation for loss or damage.



        Conclusion:
        Even in cases where a building must be constructed 50 centimeters or more distant away from the boundary line, the owner of the neighboring land may not have construction suspended or changed when a person attempts to construct a building in contact with the boundary..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 234(2), the owner of the neighboring land can only have the construction suspended or changed if the building is being constructed in violation of Article 234(1) within one year of the start of construction or before completion. The conclusion specifies cases where the building is constructed exactly at the boundary line, which is a violation of Article 234(1). However, since the conclusion addresses scenarios where the owner cannot have construction suspended or changed, it logically follows that these violations must occur beyond the one-year period or after the building's completion, aligning with the provisions of Article 234(2). Thus, the conclusion is valid given the premises.
attacking_argument: According to Article 234(2), if a person attempts to construct a building in violation of the provisions of Article 234(1), specifically constructing a building in contact with the boundary line, the owner of the neighboring land may have the construction suspended or changed. This directly contradicts the conclusion of the argument which states that the construction cannot be suspended or changed even in violation cases, thus making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 106:
(1) A subagent represents the principal with respect to acts within the scope of the authority thereof.
(2) A subagent has the same rights and obligations as an agent in relation to the principal and third parties within the scope of that subagent's authority.
(Abuse of Authority to Represent)

Article 99:
(1) A manifestation of intention that an agent makes indicating that they will be making a manifestation of intention on behalf of the principal within the scope of the agent's authority binds the principal directly.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph apply mutatis mutandis to a manifestation of intention that a third party makes to an agent.
(Manifestation of Intention That the Agent Does Not Indicate as Being Made on Behalf of the Principal)



        Conclusion:
        A subagent's acts are equivalent to an agent's acts because he/she does not act in agency for the agent, but in agency for the priciple, so it is sufficient if he/she indicates that his/her acts are made on behalf of the principle..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 106(1), a subagent represents the principal with respect to acts within the scope of the authority thereof, and Article 106(2) states that a subagent has the same rights and obligations as an agent in relation to the principal and third parties within the scope of the subagent's authority. Therefore, when a subagent indicates that their acts are made on behalf of the principal, these acts are legally binding on the principal, as per Article 99(1), which states that a manifestation of intention by an agent indicating that they will act on behalf of the principal binds the principal directly. Hence, a subagent's acts are equivalent to an agent's acts because the subagent does not act in agency for the agent but directly for the principal, making it sufficient for the subagent to indicate that their acts are made on behalf of the principal to bind the principal directly.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that a subagent's acts are equivalent to an agent's acts because the subagent indicates his/her acts are made on behalf of the principal is overly specific. According to Article 106(1) and 106(2), a subagent's acts are already bound directly to the principal without the need for additional indication, as they represent the principal within their authority. Therefore, the indication itself is a redundant condition, potentially invalidating the argument's strict logical entailment.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 306:
A person that has a claim arising from the causes set forth below has a statutory lien over the entire assets of the obligor:
(i) expenses for the common benefit;
(ii) an employer-employee relationship;
(iii) funeral expenses; or
(iv) the supply of daily necessaries.
(Statutory Liens for Expenses for Common Benefit)

Article 308:
Statutory liens for employer-employee relationships exist with respect to salaries and other claims that arise from the employer-employee relationship between the obligor and the employee.
(Statutory Liens for Funeral Expenses)



        Conclusion:
        If a company does not pay salary, the employee shall have a statutory lien with respect to the salary, regardless of the unpaid period, over the entire property of the company..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 306, a statutory lien exists over the entire assets of an obligor for claims arising from an employer-employee relationship. Article 308 further specifies that statutory liens for employer-employee relationships include unpaid salaries. Thus, if a company does not pay salaries, the unpaid salary is a claim that arises from an employer-employee relationship, leading to a statutory lien over the entire property of the company as per Article 306, regardless of the duration of non-payment.
attacking_argument: The conclusion overstates the scope of Article 306 and Article 308 by implying a statutory lien exists for any unpaid salary, regardless of the period, without specifying any limitations. The articles do not explicitly state that a lien is available for any unpaid salary regardless of the period, thus the conclusion extends beyond the scope of the provided premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 650:
(1) If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended.
(2) If the mandatary has borne any obligation found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may demand that the mandator perform the obligation on the mandatary's behalf. In such cases, if the obligation has not yet fallen due, the mandatary may require the mandator to tender reasonable security.
(3) If a mandatary incurs loss or damage that is not due to the negligence of the mandatary in order to administer the mandated business, the mandatary may claim compensation for this from the mandator.
(Cancellation of Mandate)

Article 702:
(1) If a manager has incurred beneficial expenses for a principal, the manager may claim reimbursement of those costs from the principal.
(2) The provisions of Article 650, paragraph (2) apply mutatis mutandis if a manager has incurred beneficial obligations on behalf of the principal.
(3) If a manager has engaged in the benevolent intervention in another's business against the will of the principal, the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs apply mutatis mutandis, solely to the extent currently enriched.
Chapter IV Unjust Enrichment
(Obligation to Return Unjust Enrichment)



        Conclusion:
        A person who commences the management of a business for another person without being obliged to do so may not demand compensation from the principal, even if he/she expends useful expenses for the principal, when that management is against the intention of the principal..'''
supporting_argument: If a manager engages in the management of a business for a principal without being obliged to do so and this management goes against the principal's intentions, according to Article 702(3), the manager's right to claim reimbursement or demand performance of obligations from the principal is limited to the extent that the principal is currently enriched. Since the management is against the principal's will, there is no current enrichment, hence the manager cannot claim compensation, even for useful expenses incurred for the principal, as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that a person who manages a business for another without being obliged to do so, and against the principal's will, may not demand compensation, even if they expend useful expenses for the principal, is not directly supported by the statutes provided. Article 650 and Article 702 detail the rights to reimbursement and security, but they do not explicitly state that no compensation is allowed in cases of managing against the principal's will. Thus, the conclusion overextends the scope of the given premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
