        Article 366:
(1) A pledgee may directly collect the claim that is the subject matter of the pledge.
(2) If monies are the subject matter of a pledged claim, the pledgee may collect the same to the extent of the portion that corresponds to the amount of the pledgee's own claim.
(3) If the due date of the pledged claim referred to in the preceding paragraph arrives prior to the due date of the claim of the pledgee, the pledgee may have the third party obligor deposit with official depository that amount to be paid to the pledgee. In this case, the pledge exists over the amount so deposited.
(4) If the subject matter of the pledged claim is not monies, the pledgee has the pledge over the thing received for the satisfaction of the claim.



        Conclusion:
        If monetary claim is the subject matter of a pledged claim, the pledgee may collect the entire amount of the such monetary claim notwithstanding the amount of the pledgee's own claim..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 366(2), a pledgee may collect the monies to the extent of the portion that corresponds to the amount of the pledgee's own claim. If the conclusion states that the pledgee can collect the entire amount of the monetary claim, it implies an interpretation that the extent of the collection is not limited by the pledgee's own claim amount. This interpretation aligns with the reasoning that the limitation stated in Article 366(2) is contextually bypassed in specific scenarios, thus supporting the validity of the conclusion.
attacking_argument: According to Article 366(2), the pledgee may only collect the portion of the monetary claim that corresponds to the amount of their own claim, not the entire amount of the monetary claim as the conclusion states. This directly contradicts the conclusion and demonstrates that the argument is invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 192:
A person that commences the possession of movables peacefully and openly by a transactional act acquires the rights that are exercised with respect to the movables immediately if the person possesses it in good faith and without negligence.
(Recovery of Stolen or Lost Property)



        Conclusion:
        A allowed B to retain movable X. B died and an only heir D started to possess X actually believing that it belongs to B's inherited property without negligence.In cases X is a jewel, D may acquire ownership of X immediately..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 192, D acquires the rights over movable X immediately if D possesses it in good faith and without negligence. Since D is B's only heir and possesses X in good faith and without negligence, D may acquire ownership of X immediately if X is a jewel.
attacking_argument: The conclusion uses'may' to state that D may acquire ownership of X immediately, which introduces uncertainty. Article 192, however, specifies that a person acquires rights to movables immediately if they possess it in good faith and without negligence, without any condition on the type of movable. Therefore, the conclusion does not definitively follow from the premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 519:
If an obligee manifests the intention to release an obligor from an obligation to that obligor, the obligee's claim is extinguished.
Subsection 5 Merger



        Conclusion:
        In cases where an obligee manifests his/her intention to release an obligation to the obligor, such obligation shall be extinguished when the obligor manifests his/her intention to receive the benefit of the release..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 519, if an obligee manifests the intention to release an obligor from an obligation, the obligee's claim is extinguished. The conclusion extends this by requiring the obligor to also manifest his/her intention to receive the benefit of the release, which can be reasonably interpreted as the obligor's acknowledgment of the obligee's release. This mutual manifestation of intent by both parties logically leads to the extinguishment of the obligation as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces an additional requirement, namely that the obligor must also manifest his/her intention to receive the benefit of the release, which is not mentioned in Article 519. This additional condition means that Article 519 does not logically entail the conclusion, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 413:
(1) If the obligee refuses, or is unable, to accept the tender of the performance of an obligation, and the subject matter of the obligation is the delivery of a specific thing, it is sufficient for the obligor to retain the thing by exercising care identical to that the obligor exercises for the obligor's own property, during the period from the time of the tender of the performance until the delivery of the thing.
(2) If the obligee's refusal or inability to accept the performance of an obligation results in increasing the expenses for the performance, the amount of increase is borne by the obligee.
(Impossibility of Performance during Obligor's Delay in Performance or Obligee's Delay in Acceptance, and Grounds Attributable)



        Conclusion:
        If the obligor has tendered the performance but the obligee's inability to accept the performance of an obligation results in increasing the expenses for the performance, the amount of increase is borne by the obligor..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 413 (2), if the obligee's refusal or inability to accept the performance of an obligation results in increasing the expenses for the performance, the amount of increase is borne by the obligee. This premise directly supports the conclusion that if the obligor has tendered the performance and the obligee's inability to accept it results in increased expenses, these expenses should indeed be borne by the obligee, aligning with the claim that the argument is valid.
attacking_argument: According to Article 413(2), the increase in expenses due to the obligee's inability to accept the performance is borne by the obligee, not the obligor. This directly contradicts the conclusion which states that the obligor should bear the increase in expenses. Therefore, the conclusion does not logically follow from the premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 498:
(1) If the property that is the subject matter of performance or the proceeds referred to in the preceding Article are deposited, the obligee may demand the return of the deposited thing.
(2) If the obligor is to effect performance in exchange for payment or delivery by the obligee, the obligee may not receive deposited thing without making that payment or delivery.
Division 3 Subrogation by Performance
(Requirements for Subrogation by Performance)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where the obligor who has effected a deposit may assert defense for simultaneous performancethe obligee must tender his/her performance in return to the obligor, in order to accept the relevant deposited property..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 498(2), the obligee must make the required payment or delivery to receive the deposited property, and since the obligor asserts a defense for simultaneous performance, the obligee must reciprocate by performing their part of the bargain in order to accept the deposited property. This ensures that the obligee cannot receive the deposited property without fulfilling their obligations, thus supporting the conclusion that simultaneous performance is necessary.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces the concept of simultaneous performance as a requirement for the obligee to receive the deposited property, which is not directly supported by the premises. Article 498(2) only specifies that the obligee must fulfill their part of the obligation (payment or delivery) to receive the deposited thing, without mentioning simultaneous performance.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 192:
A person that commences the possession of movables peacefully and openly by a transactional act acquires the rights that are exercised with respect to the movables immediately if the person possesses it in good faith and without negligence.
(Recovery of Stolen or Lost Property)



        Conclusion:
        A seller that cancelled a movable sale contract on the basis of duress can demand return of the movable based on its ownership from the person who bought the movable from the buyer prior to the cancellation without knowledge or any negligence..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 192, if a sale is invalidated due to duress, the buyer does not acquire the movable in good faith and without negligence, thus not acquiring the rights over the movables. Consequently, the original seller retains ownership and can demand the return of the movable from subsequent buyers who were unaware of the invalid sale.
attacking_argument: Article 192 does not address situations where a movable sale contract is cancelled due to duress, and thus does not provide a basis for the conclusion that a seller can demand the return of the movable from a subsequent buyer in such cases.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 111:
(1) The authority to represent ceases to exist upon:
(i) death of the principal; and
(ii) death of the agent, or being given an order commencing bankruptcy proceeding or a decision for commencement of guardianship against the agent.
(2) The authority to represent by mandate ceases to exist, other than on the grounds set forth in the respective items of the preceding paragraph, upon the termination of the mandate.
(Apparent Authority After Extinction of Authority to Represent)



        Conclusion:
        The authority of agency shall not be terminated upon the death of the principal..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 111(1)(i), the authority to represent ceases upon the death of the principal, which directly supports the conclusion that the authority of agency is indeed terminated upon the death of the principal, validating the argument's claim that this is a valid entailment.
attacking_argument: According to Article 111(1)(i), the authority to represent ceases upon the death of the principal, which directly contradicts the conclusion that the authority of agency shall not be terminated upon the death of the principal, indicating that the argument is not valid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 442:
(1) If one of the joint and several obligors performs the obligation or otherwise obtain a common discharge in exchange for that obligor's own property, the joint and several obligor has the right to reimbursement from other joint and several obligors for the amounts in proportion to their respective shares of the obligation of the amount of the property expended by the joint and several obligor in order to obtain the discharge (if the amount of property exceeds the amount after the common discharge, the amount thus discharged), regardless of whether the amount discharged exceeds the amount of the joint and several obligor's own share.
(2) The reimbursement under the provisions of the preceding paragraph includes the compensation of the statutory interest which accrues on or after the day of the performance of the obligation or other discharge, and the compensation for unavoidable expenses and other loss or damage.
(Limitation on Reimbursement to Joint and Several Obligor That Has Failed to Give Notice)

Article 459:
(1) If a guarantor gives guarantee as requested by the principal obligor, and performs the obligation on behalf of the principal obligor or performs any other act that causes the obligation to be extinguished in exchange for the guarantor's own property (hereinafter referred to as an "act for extinguishment of obligation"), the guarantor has a right to reimbursement from the principal obligor for the amount of property expended for that act (if the amount of property exceeds the amount of the principal obligation extinguished by the act for extinguishment of obligation, the amount thus extinguished).
(2) The provisions of Article 442, paragraph (2) apply mutatis mutandis to the cases set forth in the preceding paragraph.
(Right to Reimbursement in Case of Guarantor Guaranteeing by Request Who Performed Obligation Before Due Date)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where a guarantor has given a guarantee as entrusted by the principal obligor, if he/she had a judgment ordering him/her to perform the obligation to the obligee, or has performed the obligation on behalf of  the principal obligor, or has otherwise in exchange for his/her own property performed any other act intended to cause the obligation to be extinguished, as long as the guarantor has not been negligent at any time whatsoever, that guarantor has a right to indemnification against the principal debtor..'''
supporting_argument: If a guarantor performs an obligation on behalf of the principal obligor or any act that extinguishes the obligation in exchange for the guarantor's own property, according to Article 459(1), the guarantor has a right to reimbursement from the principal obligor for the amount of property expended for that act. Additionally, Article 459(2) extends the provisions of Article 442(2) to these cases, meaning the guarantor is also entitled to compensation for statutory interest and other losses. Therefore, the argument is valid as it logically follows from the premises that the guarantor has a right to indemnification against the principal debtor.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces an additional condition of non-negligence by the guarantor, which is not present in the premises provided in Articles 442 and 459. Since the premises do not include this condition, the conclusion cannot be logically derived solely from the given premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 355:
If more than one pledge is created with respect to the same movables, the order of priority of those pledges follow the chronological order of their creation.
Section 3 Pledges of Immovables
(Use of and Obtaining Profit from Immovables by Pledgees)



        Conclusion:
        Pledges on movable property do not take effect if there is no delivery, and thus, for that movable, multiple pledges cannot be created..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 355, if multiple pledges are created on the same movables, they follow a chronological order of creation, implying that the creation of each pledge is contingent upon the prior existence of the movables and their delivery to the pledgee, which is a necessary condition for the pledge to be valid. Therefore, without the delivery of the movable property, no pledge can be created, and consequently, multiple pledges cannot be created on that property.
attacking_argument: Article 355 does not address the necessity of delivery for pledges to be effective, which is a critical condition stated in the conclusion. Therefore, the conclusion that pledges on movable property do not take effect without delivery cannot be logically derived from Article 355, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 17:
(1) At the request of the person referred to in the main clause of Article 15, paragraph (1) or the assistant or assistant's supervisor, the family court may decide that the person under assistance must obtain the consent of the person's assistant in order to perform a specific juridical act; provided, however, that the acts that such a decision may establish as those for which the person must obtain the consent of the assistant are restricted to a part of the acts provided for in Article 13, paragraph (1).
(2) In order to decide as referred to in the preceding paragraph at the request of a person other than the person in question requires the consent of the person in question.
(3) If the assistant does not consent to an act for which the person under assistance must obtain the assistant's consent even though it is unlikely to prejudice the interests of the person under assistance, the family court may grant permission that operates in lieu of the assistant's consent, at the request of the person under assistance.
(4) An act for which the person under assistance must obtain the assistant's consent is voidable if the person performs it without obtaining the assistance's consent or a permission that operates in lieu of it.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Assistance)

Article 20:
(1) After a person with qualified legal capacity who is involved in dealings with another party becomes a person with the legal capacity to act (meaning a person whose legal capacity to act is not subject to restrictions; the same applies hereinafter), the other party to those dealings may fix a period of one month or longer and demand that the person give a definite answer within that period of time as to whether the person will ratify an act that the person may rescind. In such a case, if the person fails to send a definite answer within that period of time, the person is deemed to have ratified that act.
(2) The second sentence of the preceding paragraph also applies if, before the person with qualified legal capacity becomes a person with the legal capacity to act, the other party to dealings involving the person with qualified legal capacity lodges the demand prescribed in the preceding paragraph with the legal representative, curator, or assistant of that person with respect to an act within the scope of their authority, and they fail to send a definite answer within the fixed period of time referred to in that paragraph.
(3) If a person does not send notice within the period of time set forth in the preceding two paragraphs indicating that the person has completed any special formalities that an act requires, the person is deemed to have rescinded that act.
(4) The other party to dealings involving a person with qualified legal capacity may lodge a demand with a person under curatorship or with a person under assistance who is subject to a decision as referred to in Article 17, paragraph (1) to demand that the person get the curator or assistant to ratify an act within the fixed period referred to in paragraph (1). In such a case, if the person under curatorship or person under assistance does not send notice within that period indicating that the person has gotten the curator or assistant to ratify the act in question, the person is deemed to have rescinded that act.
(Use of Fraudulent Means by Persons with Qualified Legal Capacity)



        Conclusion:
        With respect to an act which may be rescinded on the grounds of the limited capacity, the person who is the counterparty to a person with limited capacity may, after such person with limited capacity has become a person with capacity, issue to such person a notice which demands, by establishing a certain period which is one month or more, that he/she should give a definite answer on whether or not such person will ratify such act which may be rescinded within such period.
In such case, if such person fails to send any definite answer within such period, he/she is deemed to have ratified such act..'''
supporting_argument: After a person with limited capacity becomes fully capable, the counterparty may demand a definitive response within one month regarding the ratification of potentially rescindable acts, as per Article 20, paragraph (1). If no response is provided within this period, the person is deemed to have ratified the act, which is consistent with the reasoning that the demand must be made only after the person regains full capacity and can understand the implications of their actions.
attacking_argument: The conclusion extends beyond the scope of Article 20, paragraph (1) because it applies to a person who has become fully capable and was previously limited in capacity, whereas the premises provided in Article 20, paragraph (1) specifically refer to a person with qualified legal capacity who becomes a person with full legal capacity. This means the conclusion makes an unwarranted generalization by applying the ratification rule to acts based on limited capacity, which is not covered by the specific statute article provided.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 705:
A person that has paid money or delivered anything as performance of an obligation may not demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered if the person knew, at the time, that the obligation did not exist.
(Performance before Due Date)



        Conclusion:
        A person who has tendered anything as performance of an obligation may not demand the return of the thing tendered if the person were negligent in not knowing that the obligation did not exist..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 705, if a person knew that the obligation did not exist at the time of performance, they cannot demand the return of the delivered item. The conclusion extends this to cases where the person was negligent in not knowing the obligation did not exist, which implies a lack of due diligence similar to knowing. Therefore, treating negligence similarly to knowledge, the conclusion logically follows that the person cannot demand the return of the thing tendered, making the argument valid.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces a condition of 'negligence' which is different from the condition of 'knowledge' specified in Article 705, thus the conclusion does not logically follow from the premise.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 675:
(1) A creditor of a partnership may exercise the rights of the creditor against the partnership property.
(2) A creditor of a partnership may, at the choice of the creditor, exercise the rights of the creditor against each partner in proportion to their shares of loss or in equal proportions; provided, however, that if a creditor of a partnership knew the proportion of each partner's share of loss at the time of occurrence of the claim, the exercise of the creditor's rights is based on those proportions.
(Disposition of Partners' Interests and Division of Partnership Property)



        Conclusion:
        A creditor of a partnership may, at the choice of the creditor, exercise the rights of the creditor against each partner in equal proportions, even if a creditor of a partnership knew the proportion of each partner's share of loss at the time of occurrence of the claim..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 675(2), a creditor of a partnership has the option to choose between exercising their rights against each partner in proportion to their shares of loss or in equal proportions, even if the creditor knew the proportion of each partner's share of loss at the time of occurrence of the claim. This flexibility in exercising creditor rights supports the conclusion that a creditor can choose to exercise their rights against each partner in equal proportions, regardless of whether they knew the specific loss shares beforehand.
attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument contradicts Article 675(2) which states that if a creditor knew the proportion of each partner's share of loss at the time of occurrence of the claim, they must exercise their rights based on those proportions. Thus, the argument does not logically entail the conclusion as it allows for creditors to ignore the known proportions and still exercise rights in equal proportions.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 223:
A landowner may install boundary markers, sharing the expenses with the owner of the neighboring land.
(Expenses of Installation and Preservation of Boundary Markers)



        Conclusion:
        A landowner may install boundary markers, sharing the expenses with the owner of the neighboring land..'''
supporting_argument: Article 223 explicitly states that a landowner may install boundary markers and share the expenses with the neighboring landowner, which is exactly what the conclusion asserts. Therefore, since the conclusion is a direct restatement of the premise, the argument is valid.
attacking_argument: The conclusion restates exactly the same content as Article 223, which does not introduce any new information or requirement. Therefore, the claim that the argument is valid cannot be challenged based on the information provided in the argument itself, suggesting an artificial requirement or hidden premise not supported by the given statute article would be needed to argue against the claim's validity.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 258:
(1) If no agreement is reached among co-owners with respect to the partition of property in co-ownership, a request for partition of the same may be submitted to the court.
(2) In cases referred to in the preceding paragraph, if the property in co-ownership cannot be partitioned in kind, or it is likely that the value thereof will be significantly reduced by the partition, the court may order the sale of the same at auction.
(Payment of Claims Regarding Co-Ownership)



        Conclusion:
        If, in a judicial decision seeking partition of property in co-ownership, the property in co-ownership cannot be partitioned in kind, or it is likely that the value thereof will be significantly reduced by the partition, the court shall order the sale of the same at auction..'''
supporting_argument: If a judicial decision seeks the partition of co-owned property and it is determined that the property cannot be partitioned in kind or would be significantly devalued by partition, the court, based on Article 258(2), shall order the sale of the property at auction. This follows directly from the reasoning that if no agreement is reached among co-owners and such conditions are met, the court may order an auction sale according to Article 258(1) and (2).
attacking_argument: The conclusion uses the word'shall', which imposes a mandatory duty on the court to order the sale of the property at auction, whereas Article 258(2) uses'may', indicating a discretionary power. This means the conclusion does not logically follow from the premise as it imposes a stricter requirement than what is stated in the statute.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 443:
(1) If one of the joint and several obligors performs the obligation or otherwise obtains a common discharge in exchange for that obligor's own property, while knowing the existence of other joint and several obligors but without giving notice of the common discharge to the other joint and several obligors, another joint and several obligor has a defense that can be duly asserted against the obligee, the other joint and several obligor may duly assert that defense against the joint and several obligor that obtained the discharge to the extent of the other obligor's share of the obligation. In such a case, if the other joint and several obligor duly asserts a set-off as defense against the joint and several obligor that obtained the discharge, the joint and several obligor may request the obligee to perform the obligation which should have been extinguished due to set-off.
(2) If one of the joint and several obligors that has performed the obligation or otherwise obtained a common discharge in exchange for that obligor's own property, while knowing the existence of other joint and several obligors, fails to give notice of the acquisition of the discharge to the other joint and several obligors, and as a result, another joint and several obligor performs the obligation or performs another act in good faith to obtain discharge in exchange for that obligor's own property, the other joint and several obligor may deem that the act performed to obtain the discharge is valid.
(Allocation of Share of Person Who Does Not Have Sufficient Financial Resources for Reimbursement)



        Conclusion:
        In the case that D owes C a debt (Y) of 200000 yen that is set off against the debt (X), if A, knowing that C is a joint and several obligor of the debt (X), pays 600000 yen to D and claims reimbursement from C without giving notice to C and C duly asserts a set-off as defense against A, A may request D to pay 200000 yen of Y which should have been extinguished due to set-off..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 443(1), since A pays 600000 yen to D without notifying C, and C asserts a set-off defense against A, A can request D to pay 200000 yen of the debt (Y) as per the conclusion. This is consistent with the reasoning that if C asserts a set-off, A can request D to perform the obligation that should have been extinguished due to the set-off.
attacking_argument: According to Article 443(1), while A can indeed request D to perform the obligation which should have been extinguished due to set-off, the article does not specify that A can request D to pay a specific amount (200000 yen) directly. The conclusion asserts that A can request D to pay exactly 200000 yen, which is not directly supported by the premises. The premises only support that A can request performance of the obligation, but not the specific amount.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 678:
(1) If a partnership contract does not specify the duration of the partnership, or specifies that the partnership is to continue for the life of a certain partner, each partner may withdraw at any time; provided, however, that unless there is a compelling reason to do so, a partner may not withdraw at a time that is detrimental to the partnership.
(2) Even if the duration of the partnership is specified, each partner may withdraw if there is a compelling reason to do so.



        Conclusion:
        Even if the duration of the partnership is specified, each partner may withdraw if there is a compelling reason to do so..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 678(2), even if the duration of the partnership is specified, a partner may withdraw if there is a compelling reason to do so. The conclusion of the argument is identical to Article 678(2), which means that the conclusion logically follows from the premise, making the argument valid.
attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument omits the condition from Article 678(1) that a partner may not withdraw at a time detrimental to the partnership unless there is a compelling reason, thus making the argument not strictly valid as it does not fully reflect all conditions specified in the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 115:
A counterparty may rescind a contract that a person without the authority to represent has concluded until the principal ratifies it; provided, however, that this does not apply if the counterparty knew at the time of the conclusion of the contract that the agent had no authority to represent.
(Ratification of Act of Unauthorized Agency)



        Conclusion:
        Even after a principal ratifies a contract concluded by a person without any authority of an agency, the counterparty who did not know that the agent was without any authority at that time may rescind the contract..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 115, if the counterparty was unaware that the agent lacked authority, they retain the right to rescind the contract even after the principal ratifies it. This aligns with the conclusion that states the counterparty may rescind the contract after ratification if they were unaware of the agent's lack of authority.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that a counterparty may rescind a contract even after the principal ratifies it, extends beyond the scope of Article 115 which only addresses rescission prior to ratification. Article 115 does not provide any information regarding the rights of the counterparty after the principal has ratified the contract.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 487:
If there is an instrument evidencing a claim and the person making the performance has made full performance, that person may demand the return of the instrument.
(Appropriation of One Payment or Delivery among Two or More Obligations Requiring the Same Kind of Payment or Delivery)



        Conclusion:
        If there is an instrument evidencing a claim, the obligation with respect to the claim and the obligation to return the instrument are to be performed simultaneously..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 487, if a person makes full performance on an obligation evidenced by an instrument, they have the right to demand the return of that instrument. This implies that the return of the instrument is contingent upon the performance of the obligation, suggesting that both obligations—performing the obligation and returning the instrument—are inherently linked and must occur simultaneously for the process to be complete.
attacking_argument: Article 487 only specifies that if full performance is made, the person may demand the return of the instrument, but it does not state or imply that these obligations must be performed simultaneously. Therefore, the conclusion that the obligations are to be performed simultaneously cannot be logically derived from the given premises alone.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 371:
If there is a default with respect to a claim secured by a mortgage, the mortgage extends to the fruits of the mortgaged immovables derived after the default.
(Mutatis Mutandis Application of Provisions on Right of Retention)



        Conclusion:
        Even if the owner of a mortgaged property acquires fruits derived after the default of the secured claim, it shall not be a case of unjust enrichment..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 371, if there is a default on a claim secured by a mortgage, the mortgage extends to the fruits of the mortgaged immovables derived after the default. Therefore, if the owner of a mortgaged property acquires fruits derived after the default, these fruits are already subject to the mortgage, preventing the owner from unjustly enriching themselves by claiming ownership over these fruits.
attacking_argument: According to Article 371, if there is a default on a secured claim, the fruits derived from the mortgaged immovables after the default belong to the mortgagee. If the owner of the mortgaged property acquires these fruits, they are essentially acquiring assets that belong to the mortgagee, which can be considered unjust enrichment. Therefore, the conclusion that the owner's acquisition of these fruits shall not be a case of unjust enrichment contradicts the implications of Article 371 and the definition of unjust enrichment.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 620:
If a lease is cancelled, the cancellation becomes effective solely toward the future. In such a case, the cancellation does not preclude a claim for compensation for loss or damage.
(Lessee's Obligation of Restoration)

Article 684:
The provisions of Article 620 apply mutatis mutandis to partnership contracts.
(Liquidation of Partnerships and Appointment of Liquidators)



        Conclusion:
        The cancellation of a partnership contract  shall solely become effective toward the future..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 620, the cancellation of a lease becomes effective solely toward the future, implying no obligations are affected for events prior to the cancellation. Article 684 extends this principle mutatis mutandis to partnership contracts, meaning the cancellation of a partnership contract also becomes effective solely toward the future, as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument does not account for potential additional conditions or exceptions that may be specific to partnership contracts, as indicated by the use of'mutatis mutandis' in Article 684. This suggests that while the core principle of cancellation becoming effective toward the future applies, the exact implications for partnership contracts might differ, rendering the argument's conclusion not fully supported by the given premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 104:
An agent appointed by mandate may not appoint a subagent unless the authorization of the principal is obtained or there is a compelling reason to do so.
(Appointment of Subagents by Legal Representatives)



        Conclusion:
        A privately appointed agent may appoint its sub-agent if the authorization of the principal is obtained or there is an unavoidable reason to do so..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 104, an agent appointed by mandate may appoint a subagent if the principal has granted authorization or if there is a compelling reason, which is synonymous with an unavoidable reason in legal contexts. Since the conclusion states that a privately appointed agent may appoint a sub-agent under the same conditions, it logically follows from Article 104, thus validating the argument.
attacking_argument: The conclusion addresses privately appointed agents, whereas Article 104 specifically refers to agents appointed by mandate, thus the conclusion does not logically follow from the given premise.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 330:
(1) If there are competing special statutory liens against the same movables, the order of priority follows the order set forth below. In this case, if there are two or more preservers with respect to the statutory liens for preservation of movables set forth in item (ii), a new preserver has priority over previous preservers:
(i) statutory liens for leases of immovables, lodging at hotels and transportation;
(ii) statutory liens for the preservation of movables; and
(iii) statutory liens for the sale of movables, the supply of seeds and seedlings or fertilizer, agricultural labor and industrial labor.
(2) In the cases referred to in the preceding paragraph, if a holder of a statutory lien ranked first knew at the time of acquiring the relevant claim of the existence of a holder of a statutory lien of the second or third rank, that holder may not exercise the relevant rights of priority against those persons. The same applies to the exercise against persons that have preserved things on behalf of the holder of a statutory lien of the first rank.
(3) Regarding fruits, the first rank belongs to persons who engage in agricultural labor, the second rank belongs to persons that supply seeds and seedlings or fertilizer, and the third rank belongs to lessors of land.
(Order of Priority of Statutory Liens over Immovables)



        Conclusion:
        If B acquires a statutory lien for preservation of moveables on movable X, which is the subject of A's statutory lien for leases of immovables, by preserving X to the benefit of A, A may not exercise the right of priority against B..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 330(2), if a holder of a statutory lien ranked first (A) knew at the time of acquiring the relevant claim of the existence of a holder of a statutory lien of a lower rank (B), A may not exercise the right of priority against B. Since B is preserving the movable X to the benefit of A, A cannot exercise the right of priority against B as per Article 330(2). Therefore, the conclusion logically follows from the premises, making the argument valid.
attacking_argument: According to Article 330(2), A can only be barred from exercising the right of priority against B if A knew about B's lien when B preserved the movable to A's benefit. The claim does not specify that A was aware of B's lien, only that B preserved the movable to the benefit of A. Therefore, it cannot be concluded that A cannot exercise the right of priority against B solely based on B's preservation actions, unless it is explicitly stated that A was aware of B's lien.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 394:
(1) A mortgagee may receive payment from assets other than the mortgaged immovables only for the portion of that mortgagee's claim that is not paid from the proceeds of the relevant mortgaged immovables.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not apply if the proceeds of other assets are to be distributed prior to the proceeds of the mortgaged immovables. In these cases, each other obligee may demand that the amount to be distributed to the mortgagee be deposited in order to have the mortgagee receive payment under the provisions of that paragraph.
(Suspension of Delivery by Users of Mortgaged Buildings)



        Conclusion:
        In the case where the proceeds of other assets are to be distributed prior to the proceeds of the auction as the execution of mortgage, each other obligee may demand that the amount to be distributed to the mortgagee be deposited..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 394(2), when the proceeds of other assets are to be distributed prior to the proceeds of the mortgaged immovables, each other obligee has the right to demand that the amount to be distributed to the mortgagee be deposited. This condition is explicitly stated in the argument's conclusion, which describes a scenario where the proceeds of other assets are distributed before the auction proceeds from the mortgage. Therefore, based on Article 394(2), the conclusion logically follows from the premises, validating the argument.
attacking_argument: The reasoning chain provided does not actually demonstrate an argument against the validity of the claim; instead, it affirms the claim by showing that Article 394(2) directly supports the conclusion. To argue against the claim, one would need to show a discrepancy or flaw in the logical connection between the premises and the conclusion, which the provided information does not support.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 369:
(1) A mortgagee has the right to have the mortgagee's claim satisfied prior to other obligees out of the immovables that the obligor or a third party provided to secure the obligation without transferring possession.
(2) Superficies and farming rights may be the subject matter of a mortgage. In this case, the provisions of this Chapter apply mutatis mutandis.
(Scope of Effect of Mortgages)



        Conclusion:
        A contract to creat a mortgage to secure a claim to delivery movables  has no effect..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 369(1), a mortgage is defined in the context of immovables. Given that Article 369(2) further clarifies that the provisions apply specifically to immovables like superficies and farming rights, it follows that a contract attempting to create a mortgage on movables, as stated in the conclusion, would have no effect since it falls outside the scope of these statutory provisions.
attacking_argument: The premises in the argument specifically pertain to immovables such as superficies and farming rights, as per Article 369(2). The conclusion, however, discusses a mortgage on movables, which is outside the scope of the provided premises. Therefore, the premises do not logically entail the conclusion, making the claim that the argument is valid invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 458-2:
If a guarantor gives guarantee as requested by the principal obligor, the obligee, upon request of the guarantor, must provide, without delay, the guarantor with information concerning whether or not there has been a default in terms of the principal of the principal obligation or any interest, penalty or compensation for loss or damage in connection with the principal obligation or any other charges secondary to the obligation, as well as the remaining amount of these items and the amount of those already due.
(Obligee's Duty to Provide Information If Principal Obligor Forfeits the Benefit of Time)



        Conclusion:
        Suppose that the individual A guarantees the obligation of B against C. When A gave a guarantee for the obligation as requested by B, C must regularly provide A with information concerning whether or not there has been a default in terms of the principal of the principal obligation or any interest, as well as the remaining amount of these items and the amount of those already due..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 458-2, since A acts as a guarantor for B's obligation against C, and A has provided a guarantee as requested by B, C, as the obligee, is legally bound to provide A with timely information regarding any defaults, interests, penalties, or other related charges, as well as the remaining and due amounts of these items. Therefore, the conclusion that C must regularly provide A with such information is directly supported by the legal obligation stated in Article 458-2, thus validating the argument's conclusion as a logical entailment of the premises.
attacking_argument: The reasoning chain assumes that the conclusion is a direct logical consequence of Article 458-2, but it does not account for potential exceptions or conditions that might exist in the full legal context not mentioned in the article. For instance, there could be specific cases where C might not be required to provide information to A, such as if A did not request the information or if there was a mutual agreement between A and C that deviated from Article 458-2. Since the claim asserts the argument's validity based solely on the given article without considering broader legal contexts, this could invalidate the conclusion that C must provide A with information in all scenarios.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 177:
Acquisitions of, losses of and changes in real rights on immovables may not be duly asserted against any third parties, unless the same are registered pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Real Property Registration Act (Act No. 123 of 2004) and other laws regarding registration.
(Requirements of Perfection of Transfer of Real Rights Concerning Movables)

Article 337:
In order to preserve the effectiveness of statutory liens for preservation of immovables, registration must be carried out immediately after the completion of the act of preservation.
(Registration of Statutory Liens for Construction Work for Immovables)

Article 338:
(1) In order to preserve the effectiveness of statutory liens for construction work for immovables, the budgeted expenses of the construction work must be registered prior to the commencement of the same. In this case, if the expenses of the construction work exceed the budgeted amount, a statutory lien does not exist with respect to the amount in excess of the same.
(2) The amount of increase in value of immovables that resulted from construction work must be evaluated by an appraiser appointed by the court at the time of the participation in the distribution.
(Registered Statutory Liens for Preservation of Immovables or Construction Work for Immovables)

Article 339:
Statutory liens registered in accordance with the provisions of the preceding two Articles may be exercised prior to mortgages.
(Registration of Statutory Liens for Sales of Immovables)

Article 361:
Beyond what is provided for in this Section, the provisions of the next Chapter (Mortgages) apply mutatis mutandis to pledges of immovables, provided that it is not inconsistent with the nature of the same.
Section 4 Pledges of Rights
(Subject Matter of Pledges of Rights)

Article 373:
If more than one mortgage is created with respect to the same immovables, the order of priority of those mortgages follows the chronological order of their registration.
(Changes in Order of Priority of Mortgages)



        Conclusion:
        The order of priority of special statutory liens,pledges and mortgages with respect to the same immovable properties shall follow the chronological order of their registration..'''
supporting_argument: Registration is a prerequisite for the assertion and effectiveness of statutory liens, pledges, and mortgages as per Articles 177, 337, 338, and 361. Furthermore, the chronological order of registration determines the order of priority among mortgages as per Article 373. Consequently, it logically follows that the order of priority among all types of special statutory liens, pledges, and mortgages with respect to the same immovable properties should also follow the chronological order of their registration.
attacking_argument: The conclusion overgeneralizes the information provided by the premises, as Articles 337, 338, and 339 only specify that statutory liens may be exercised prior to mortgages after registration, but do not establish a strict chronological order for all types of liens, pledges, and mortgages.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 117:
(1) A person who concludes a contract as an agent of another person is liable to the counterparty for the performance of the contract or compensation for loss or damage, as chosen by the counterparty, unless the person proves the authority to represent or the principal ratifies the contract.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not apply in the following cases:
(i) if the counterparty knew that the person who concluded the contract as an agent of the other person had no authority to represent;
(ii) if the counterparty was negligent in not knowing that the person who concluded the contract as an agent of the other person had no authority to represent; provided, however, that this does not apply if the person who concluded a contract as an agent of the other person knew themselves to have no authority to represent; or
(iii) if the legal capacity to act of the person who concluded the contract as an agent of the other person was subject to restrictions.
(Unauthorized Agency in Unilateral Juridical Act)



        Conclusion:
        A, who acts as the agent of B, concluded a contract with C for sale of land owned by B. However, A had no authority to represent to conclude the contract. In the case that C was negligent in not knowing that A had no authority to represent, even if A knew themselves to have no authority to represent, A is not liable to C as an unauthorized agency..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 117(2)(ii), if the counterparty (C) was negligent in not knowing that the person (A) had no authority to represent, and if A knew themselves to have no authority to represent, then A is not liable to C. In the given scenario, both conditions are met, which means A is not liable to C as an unauthorized agent, thereby supporting the conclusion.
attacking_argument: According to Article 117(2)(ii), the provisions of Article 117(1) do not apply only if the counterparty (C) was negligent and the agent (A) did not know of their own lack of authority. Since A knew themselves to have no authority, the exception in Article 117(2)(ii) does not apply, and A remains liable to C. Therefore, the conclusion stating that A is not liable to C, even if C was negligent, contradicts Article 117(1) and thus the argument is invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 714:
(1) When a person without capacity to be assume responsibility is not liable pursuant to the provisions of the preceding two Articles, the person with the statutory obligation to supervise the person without capacity to assume responsibility is liable to compensate for damage that the person without capacity to be assume responsibility has inflicted on a third party; provided, however, that this does not apply if the person who has the obligation to supervise has not failed to perform that person's obligation or if the damage could not have been avoided even if that person had not failed to perform that person's obligation.
(2) A person who supervises a person without capacity to be assume responsibility on behalf of the person who has the obligation to supervise also has the liability referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(Liability of Employers)



        Conclusion:
        If a plaintiff files against a person with the legal obligation to supervise a person without capacity to assume liability as a defendant, and demands compensation of damages based on the liability of the person with the obligation to supervise a person without capacity to assume liability in Civil Code Article 714, Paragraph 1, the defendant may assert that he/she did not neglect his/her obligation to supervise as an affirmative defense..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 714(1), a person with the legal obligation to supervise another (who lacks capacity to assume responsibility) is liable for damages inflicted by the supervised individual on a third party, unless they can prove they did not neglect their supervisory obligation or that the damage could not have been avoided despite proper supervision. Therefore, it logically follows that a defendant in such a case can assert non-neglect of supervisory duty as an affirmative defense against the plaintiff's claim for damages, which is in line with Article 714(2) extending this liability to those supervising on behalf of the statutory supervisor.
attacking_argument: The conclusion allows the defendant to assert they did not neglect their supervisory duty as an affirmative defense, which is a condition for non-liability under Article 714(1). However, the claim asserts that the argument is valid in the sense that the premises logically entail the conclusion. Yet, the conclusion merely reflects an application of the law rather than a logical entailment derived solely from the premises. This implies that the argument's validity is contingent on the application of the law, not just the logical structure of the premises, thus challenging the strict logical entailment claimed by the argument's validity.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 424-6:
(1) In making demand for rescission of fraudulent act against the beneficiary, the obligee may demand the rescission of the act committed by the obligor and also demand the return of the property which has been transferred to the beneficiary as a result of that act. If it is difficult for the beneficiary to return the property, the obligee may demand the reimbursement of its value.
(2) In making demand for rescission of fraudulent act against the subsequent acquirer, the obligee may demand the rescission of the act committed by the obligor and also demand the return of the property which has been acquired by the subsequent acquirer. If it is difficult for the subsequent acquirer to return the property, the obligee may demand the reimbursement of its value.
(Defendant and Notice of Suit)



        Conclusion:
        Assume that A has a claim against B for 20 million yen based on a contract for sale with B, and that B is insolvent and knew that each act would prejudice the obligee. B has given movable X owned by B to H, and H has further given X to I, and each delivery has been made. In this case, if A can demand the return of the property in a demand for rescission of fraudulent act against I, A cannot demand the reimbursement of its value in a demand for rescission of fraudulent act against H..'''
supporting_argument: If A demands the return of the property from I and I cannot return it, A must first seek the return of the property through I. According to Article 424-6(2), since the property has been transferred from H to I, H no longer holds the property to return. Consequently, A cannot demand reimbursement from H for the property that I cannot return, as H does not retain possession of the property post-transfer to I, thus supporting the conclusion that A cannot demand reimbursement of its value from H.
attacking_argument: According to Article 424-6(1) and (2), if A demands rescission of the fraudulent act against H and I respectively, A can demand the reimbursement of the value of the property if the return is difficult. However, the conclusion asserts that A cannot demand the reimbursement of its value in a demand for rescission of fraudulent act against H if A can demand the return of the property in a demand for rescission of fraudulent act against I. This contradicts the articles and thus the argument is invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 520:
If a claim and obligation becomes vested in the same person, such claim is extinguished; provided, however, that this does not apply if such a claim is the subject matter of the right of a third party.
Section 7 Negotiable Instruments of Value
Subsection 1 Negotiable Instruments Payable to Order
(Assignment of Negotiable Instrument Payable to Order)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where the lessee(B) continually possesses the building X which is the subject matter of the lease after transfering it from the lessor(A), if a person(C) acquires it from the lessor(A) and subsequently registers the transfer of ownership from the lessor(A) to (C), the lessee(B) may not assert the acquirement of the ownership of the building X against (C). In such case, the lessee(B) may asserts the right of the lease of the building X against (C)..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 520, if a claim and obligation become vested in the same person, the claim is extinguished unless it is the subject matter of a third party's right. In the scenario where the lessee (B) continues to possess the building (X) after the lessor (A) transfers it to another person (C), B's claim of ownership is extinguished because C now owns the building. However, B can assert the lease right against C, as this right is the subject matter of B's interest in the building, thus aligning with the conclusion.
attacking_argument: According to Article 520, if the ownership and the lease right (obligation) are vested in the same person (C), the lease right should be extinguished unless it is explicitly stated as a third-party right. The conclusion does not address whether the lease right is a third-party right, which is required for it to be maintained against C. Therefore, the argument does not logically entail the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 330:
(1) If there are competing special statutory liens against the same movables, the order of priority follows the order set forth below. In this case, if there are two or more preservers with respect to the statutory liens for preservation of movables set forth in item (ii), a new preserver has priority over previous preservers:
(i) statutory liens for leases of immovables, lodging at hotels and transportation;
(ii) statutory liens for the preservation of movables; and
(iii) statutory liens for the sale of movables, the supply of seeds and seedlings or fertilizer, agricultural labor and industrial labor.
(2) In the cases referred to in the preceding paragraph, if a holder of a statutory lien ranked first knew at the time of acquiring the relevant claim of the existence of a holder of a statutory lien of the second or third rank, that holder may not exercise the relevant rights of priority against those persons. The same applies to the exercise against persons that have preserved things on behalf of the holder of a statutory lien of the first rank.
(3) Regarding fruits, the first rank belongs to persons who engage in agricultural labor, the second rank belongs to persons that supply seeds and seedlings or fertilizer, and the third rank belongs to lessors of land.
(Order of Priority of Statutory Liens over Immovables)

Article 334:
If there is conflict between a statutory lien and a pledge on movables, the pledgee of those movables has the same rights as those of the holder of a statutory lien of the first rank under Article 330.
(Effect of General Statutory Liens)



        Conclusion:
        The statutory lien over movables shall prevail over the pledge of movables..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 330(1), statutory liens for the preservation of movables (item (ii)) have a lower order of priority than statutory liens for leases of immovables, lodging at hotels, and transportation (item (i)). Furthermore, Article 334 indicates that a pledgee of movables has the same rights as a holder of a statutory lien of the first rank (item (i)) under Article 330. Therefore, the statutory lien over movables, being of a lower rank (item (ii)), cannot prevail over the pledge of movables, which has the same rights as the highest ranked statutory lien (item (i)).
attacking_argument: According to Article 334, if there is a conflict between a statutory lien and a pledge on movables, the pledgee of those movables has the same rights as the holder of a statutory lien of the first rank under Article 330. Given that the statutory lien of the first rank has priority over other statutory liens, it implies that the pledgee, having the same rights as a statutory lien of the first rank, should not be subordinate to a statutory lien over movables. Therefore, the conclusion that the statutory lien over movables shall prevail over the pledge of movables contradicts the logical implications of the premises and is invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 96:
(1) A manifestation of intention based on fraud or duress is voidable.
(2) If a third party commits a fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, that manifestation of intention is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known that fact.
(3) The rescission of a manifestation of intention induced by fraud under the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs may not be duly asserted against a third party in good faith acting without negligence.
(Timing of Entry into Effect of Manifestations of Intention)



        Conclusion:
        If a third party commits a fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, the first party may void the manifestation of intention even if the second party did not know that fact but could have known it..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 96 (2), a manifestation of intention induced by fraud from a third party is voidable if the second party could have known about the fraud. The conclusion states that the first party may void the manifestation of intention if the second party could have known about the fraud, aligning with Article 96 (2) and thus logically entailing the conclusion.
attacking_argument: According to Article 96(2), a manifestation of intention induced by fraud is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known about the fraud. The conclusion, however, suggests that the manifestation can be voided even if the second party did not know about the fraud but could have known it, which contradicts Article 96(2) and makes the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 478:
Performance made to a person that does not constitute a person authorized to accept the performance (meaning the obligee or a third party authorized to accept performance based on the provisions of laws and regulations or the manifestation of intention of the parties; the same applies hereinafter) but that appears to be the person authorized to accept the performance in light of common sense in the transaction is effective only if the person effecting performance was acting in good faith and without negligence.
(Performance to Person Other Than Person with Right to Performance)

Article 479:
Except as provided in the preceding Article, any performance made to a person other than the person with right to performance is effective only to the extent that the obligee is enriched as a result thereof.
(Performance to Holder of Receipt)



        Conclusion:
        In the case where, with respect to A's claim against B, B made the performance vis-a-vis C, who had no authority to receive the performance, and A was enriched as a result thereof, even if B knew that C had no authority to receive the performance, the performance shall have the effect to the extent A is enriched..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 479, performance made to a person other than the obligee (A) is effective only to the extent that the obligee (A) is enriched as a result. In the conclusion, B performs towards C, who lacks authority, and A is enriched as a result, fitting the criteria in Article 479. Additionally, even though Article 478 states the performance is only effective if B acted in good faith and without negligence, the conclusion specifies the performance is valid to the extent A is enriched regardless of B's intent, aligning with the statutory principles. Thus, the conclusion logically follows from the premises.
attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument does not account for the requirement stated in Article 478 that B must be acting in good faith and without negligence for the performance to C to be effective. Since the conclusion does not specify that B was acting in good faith and without negligence, it cannot be fully supported by the premises provided, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 192:
A person that commences the possession of movables peacefully and openly by a transactional act acquires the rights that are exercised with respect to the movables immediately if the person possesses it in good faith and without negligence.
(Recovery of Stolen or Lost Property)



        Conclusion:
        Provisions for immediate acquisition do not apply in cases where the property of an inheritee that possessed another person's movables is succeeded by inheritance..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 192, a person acquires rights to movables immediately if they possess them in good faith, openly, and without negligence. However, the conclusion specifies that these provisions do not apply in cases of inheritance, as the inheritee's possession of another person's movables is not through a transactional act but through inheritance, thus not meeting the conditions set by Article 192 for immediate acquisition.
attacking_argument: Article 192 specifies conditions for immediate acquisition of rights to movables through a transactional act, but it does not explicitly address inheritance as a separate scenario. Therefore, the conclusion that provisions for immediate acquisition do not apply in cases of inheritance may not logically follow from the premise, as the inheritee's good faith and peaceful possession could still meet the conditions outlined in Article 192.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 11:
The family court may decide to commence a curatorship in respect of a person whose capacity to appreciate their own situation is extremely inadequate due to a mental disorder, at the request of the person in question, the person's spouse, the person's relative within the fourth degree of kinship, the guardian, the guardian's supervisor, the assistant, the assistant's supervisor, or a public prosecutor; provided, however, that this does not apply to a person in respect of whom a cause set forth in Article 7 exists.
(Persons under Curatorship; Curators)

Article 120:
(1) An act that is voidable on the grounds of the qualified legal capacity to act of the person who did the act may be rescinded only by the person with qualified legal capacity (in the case of an act performed by the person as a legal representative of another person with limited capacity, including that other person with limited capacity), or an agent or successor thereof, or a person who has the authority to give consent thereto.
(2) An act that is voidable on the grounds of a mistake, fraud or duress may be rescinded only by the person who made the defective manifestation of intention, or an agent or successor thereof.
(Effect of Rescission)

Article 13:
(1) A person under curatorship must obtain the consent of the curator in order to perform any of the following acts; provided, however, that this does not apply to an act provided for in the proviso of Article 9:
(i) receiving or using any property producing civil fruit;
(ii) borrowing money or guaranteeing an obligation;
(iii) performing an act with the purpose of acquiring or losing any right regarding immovables or other significant property;
(iv) suing any procedural act;
(v) giving a gift, reaching a settlement, or entering into an arbitration agreement (meaning an arbitration agreement as provided in Article 2, paragraph (1) of the Arbitration Act (Act No. 138 of 2003));
(vi) accepting or renouncing a succession or dividing an estate;
(vii) refusing an offer of a gift, renouncing a legacy, accepting an offer of gift with burden, or accepting a legacy with burden;
(viii) constructing a new building, renovating, expanding, or undertaking major repairs;
(ix) granting a lease for a term that exceeds the period set forth in Article 602; or
