(x) performing any of the acts set forth in the preceding items as a legal representative of a person with qualified legal capacity (meaning a minor, adult ward, or person under curatorship or a person under assistance who is subject to a decision as referred to in Article 17, paragraph (1); the same applies hereinafter).
(2) At the request of a person as referred to in the main clause of Article 11 or the curator or curator's supervisor, the family court may decide that the person under curatorship must also obtain the consent of the curator before performing an act other than those set forth in each of the items of the preceding paragraph; provided, however, that this does not apply to an act provided for in the proviso to Article 9.
(3) If the curator does not consent to an act for which the person under curatorship must obtain the curator's consent even though it is unlikely to prejudice the interests of the person under curatorship, the family court may grant permission that operates in lieu of the curator's consent at the request of the person under curatorship.
(4) An act for which the person under curatorship must obtain the curator's consent is voidable if the person performs it without obtaining the curator's consent or a permission that operates in lieu of it.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Curatorship)

Article 17:
(1) At the request of the person referred to in the main clause of Article 15, paragraph (1) or the assistant or assistant's supervisor, the family court may decide that the person under assistance must obtain the consent of the person's assistant in order to perform a specific juridical act; provided, however, that the acts that such a decision may establish as those for which the person must obtain the consent of the assistant are restricted to a part of the acts provided for in Article 13, paragraph (1).
(2) In order to decide as referred to in the preceding paragraph at the request of a person other than the person in question requires the consent of the person in question.
(3) If the assistant does not consent to an act for which the person under assistance must obtain the assistant's consent even though it is unlikely to prejudice the interests of the person under assistance, the family court may grant permission that operates in lieu of the assistant's consent, at the request of the person under assistance.
(4) An act for which the person under assistance must obtain the assistant's consent is voidable if the person performs it without obtaining the assistance's consent or a permission that operates in lieu of it.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Assistance)

Article 2:
This Code must be construed so as to honor the dignity of individuals and the essential equality of both sexes.
Chapter II Persons
Section 1 Capacity to Hold Rights

Article 602:
If a person with no authority of disposition makes a lease contract, the leases set forth in the following items must not exceed the terms specified in those items; any longer term specified by a contract is reduced to the term specified in the relevant item:
(i) leases of forest for the purpose of planting or felling trees: 10 years;
(ii) leases of land other than the leases set forth in the preceding item: five years;
(iii) lease of a building: three years; and
(iv) lease of movables: six months.
(Renewal of Short-Term Leases)

Article 9:
A juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable; provided, however, that this does not apply to the purchase of daily necessities or to any other act involved in day-to-day life.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Guardianship)



        Conclusion:
        In the case where a person under curatorship obtains the consent of his/her curator to conclude the contract of guarantee before concluding such contract, he/she may not cancel concluding such contract by self-determination..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 13(1), a person under curatorship must obtain the consent of the curator before performing certain acts, including concluding a contract of guarantee. Furthermore, as stated in Article 13(4), an act performed by a person under curatorship without obtaining the required consent is voidable, but if consent is obtained, the act is binding and cannot be cancelled by the person under curatorship. Therefore, the conclusion that a person under curatorship may not cancel concluding a contract of guarantee after obtaining the curator's consent is logically valid based on the premises provided.
attacking_argument: According to Article 13, an act performed by a person under curatorship, such as concluding a contract of guarantee, is voidable if performed without the curator's consent. However, the conclusion of the argument states that after obtaining consent from the curator, the person under curatorship may not cancel the contract by self-determination, which contradicts the voidable nature of the act as stated in Article 13. This contradiction suggests that the argument's conclusion does not logically follow from the premises, thus invalidating the claim that the argument is valid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 566:
If the subject matter delivered by the seller to the buyer does not conform to the terms of the contract with respect to the kind or quality, and the buyer fails to notify the seller of the non-conformity within one year from the time when the buyer becomes aware of it, the buyer may not demand cure of the non-conformity of performance, demand a reduction of the price, claim compensation for loss or damage, or cancel the contract, on the grounds of the non-conformity; provided, however, that this does not apply if the seller knew or did not know due to gross negligence the non-conformity at the time of the delivery.
(Transfer of Risk for Loss of Subject Matter)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where an easement that was referred to as being in existence for the benefit of a land that is the subject matter of a sale, does not exist, the cancellation of the contract must be made within one year from the time when the buyer comes to know the facts..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 566, if the buyer does not notify the seller of the non-conformity within one year of becoming aware of it, they lose the right to cancel the contract unless the seller was aware or grossly negligent. The conclusion stating that the buyer must cancel the contract within one year of becoming aware of a non-existent easement directly aligns with this principle, thereby logically following from the premise.
attacking_argument: Article 566 specifically addresses non-conformity issues regarding the kind or quality of the subject matter delivered, not the existence of an easement. Therefore, the conclusion that the buyer must cancel the contract within one year if an easement does not exist is not supported by the premise, indicating the argument is invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 563:
(1) In the case prescribed in the main clause of paragraph (1) of the preceding Article, if the buyer demands that the seller cure the non-conformity of performance by specifying a reasonable period of time but the non-conformity of performance is not cured within that period, the buyer may request a reduction of the price in proportion to the degree of non-conformity.
(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, in the following cases, a buyer in good faith may request a reduction of the price immediately without making demand referred to in that paragraph:
(i) if it is impossible to cure the non-conformity of performance;
(ii) if the seller unequivocally manifests the intention to refuse to cure the non-conformity of performance;
(iii) if, due to the nature of the contract or a manifestation of intention by the parties, the purpose of the contract is unable to be achieved unless the performance is carried out at a specific time on a specific date or within a certain period of time, and the seller fails to cure the non-conformity of the performance at the time or before the period expires; or
(iv) beyond the cases set forth in the preceding items, it is obvious that the seller is unlikely to cure the non-conformity of the performance even if the buyer makes the demand referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(3) If the non-conformity referred to in paragraph (1) is due to grounds attributable to the buyer, the buyer may not request a reduction of the price under the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs.
(Claim for Compensation for Loss or Damage and Exercise of Right to Cancel by Buyer)

Article 565:
The provisions of the preceding three Articles apply mutatis mutandis if the right transferred by the seller to the buyer does not conform to the terms of the contract (including the case in which the seller fails to transfer part of a right that belongs to another person).
(Limitation on Period of Warranty with Respect to Kind or Quality of Subject Matter)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where a portion of purchased land is owned by a person other than the seller, and the buyer knows this at the time when the contract is concluded, if the seller cannot transfer this to the buyer, the buyer cannot demand the seller.'''
supporting_argument: If the buyer was aware that a portion of the purchased land was owned by a person other than the seller at the time of the contract, and the seller cannot transfer this portion, then according to Article 563(3) and the extension provided in Article 565, the non-conformity is due to grounds attributable to the buyer. Therefore, the buyer cannot request the seller to transfer this portion of the land, supporting the conclusion that the buyer cannot demand the seller to do so.
attacking_argument: According to Article 563(2), a buyer in good faith can request an immediate price reduction if it is impossible to cure the non-conformity of performance, regardless of whether the buyer knew about the non-conformity at the time of contract. The conclusion, however, states that the buyer cannot demand the seller if the non-conformity is known and the seller cannot transfer the portion of land. This contradicts Article 563(2), implying that the argument's premises do not logically entail the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 345:
A pledgee may not allow a pledgor to possess the thing pledged on behalf of the pledgee.
(Scope of Secured Claims under Pledges)



        Conclusion:
        A pledgee of movables may not have a pledgor possess the thing pledged on behalf of the pledgee..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 345, a pledgee is prohibited from allowing a pledgor to possess the pledged item on their behalf, which logically extends to movables as specified in the conclusion. Thus, the conclusion that a pledgee of movables may not have a pledgor possess the thing pledged on their behalf is a direct application of Article 345 and is therefore valid.
attacking_argument: The premise in Article 345 does not specify that the restriction applies exclusively to movables, yet the conclusion draws a specific case to movables, potentially overreaching the scope of the premise. If Article 345 was intended to be universally applicable, it would not require the additional specification of movables in the conclusion, thus the conclusion may not be logically entailed by the premise alone.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 654:
If a mandate has terminated but there are pressing circumstances, the mandatary or the heir or legal representative thereof must effect the necessary actions until the time when the mandator or the heir or legal representative of the mandatary is able to take charge of the mandated business.
(Requirements for Assertion of Termination of Mandate)



        Conclusion:
        Even if the mandate contract has terminated due to the death of the mandator, if there are pressing circumstances, the mandatary must effect the necessary actions until the time when the heir of the mandator is able to take charge of the mandated business..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 654, if a mandate terminates due to the death of the mandator and there are pressing circumstances, the mandatary must continue to act on the mandate until the heir of the mandator can take charge, which directly supports the conclusion of the argument.
attacking_argument: The conclusion incorrectly narrows the responsibility outlined in Article 654 to only the mandatary, ignoring the possibility that the heir or legal representative of the mandatary could also be responsible for the actions.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 298:
(1) The holder of a right of retention must possess the thing retained with the due care of a prudent manager.
(2) The holder of the right of retention may not use, lease or provide as a security the thing retained unless that holder obtains the consent of the obligor; provided, however, that this does not apply to uses necessary for the preservation of that thing.
(3) If the holder of a right of retention violates the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs, the obligor may demand that the right of retention be terminated.
(Demands for Reimbursement of Expenses by Holders of Rights of Retention)

Article 304:
(1) A statutory lien may also be exercised against things including monies that the obligor is to receive as a result of the sale, lease or loss of, or damage to, the subject matter of the statutory lien; provided, however, that the holder of the statutory lien must attach the same before the payment or delivery of the monies or other thing.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph also apply to the consideration for real rights created by the obligor on the subject matter of the statutory lien.
(Indivisibility of Statutory Liens)

Article 350:
The provisions of Articles 296 through 300 and those of Article 304 apply mutatis mutandis to pledges.
(Third-Party Collateral Providers' Rights to Reimbursement)



        Conclusion:
        A pledgee must possess a pledged Thing with the  care of a good manager..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 298(1), holders of a right of retention must possess the retained thing with the due care of a prudent manager. Article 350 extends these provisions to pledges, meaning a pledgee must also possess the pledged thing with the care of a prudent manager. Hence, the conclusion that a pledgee must possess a pledged Thing with the care of a good manager logically follows from the premises.
attacking_argument: The conclusion states that a pledgee must possess a pledged thing with the care of a 'good' manager, whereas Article 298 specifies the care required is that of a 'prudent' manager. While these terms might be synonymous in some contexts, the argument does not provide evidence that 'good' manager is equivalent to 'prudent' manager in the specific context of managing pledged things. Therefore, the conclusion may not logically follow from the premises as stated.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 134:
A juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.
(Effect of Arrival of Assigned Time)



        Conclusion:
        A juristic act which is subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent on  the willof the obligor..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 134, a juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor. The conclusion states that a juristic act which is subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent on the will of the obligor. Since 'intention' and 'will' are synonymous in this context, and 'juridical act' and 'juristic act' can be considered the same, the conclusion logically follows from the premise, thus validating the argument.
attacking_argument: The conclusion uses the phrase 'dependent on the will of the obligor,' which is broader than the phrase 'dependent only upon the intention of the obligor' used in Article 134. This difference in specificity means that Article 134 does not logically entail the conclusion as stated.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:

        Article 644:
A mandatary bears a duty to administer the mandated business with the due care of a prudent manager in compliance with the main purport of the mandate.
(Appointment of Sub-Mandatary)



        Conclusion:
        Even under a gratuitous mandate contract, the mandatary must administer the mandated business with the due care of a prudent manager in compliance with the main purport of the mandate..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 644, the duty of a mandatary to administer the mandated business with the due care of a prudent manager applies universally to all types of mandates, including gratuitous ones, thus logically entailing the conclusion that even under a gratuitous mandate, the mandatary must administer the mandated business with due care.
attacking_argument: Article 644 does not specify whether the mandate is gratuitous or not, thus it cannot be concluded that the duty of administering the mandated business with due care applies specifically to gratuitous mandates.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 706:
If an obligor has paid money or delivered anything as performance of an obligation that has not yet fallen due, the obligor may not demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered; provided, however, that if the obligor tendered anything by mistake, the obligee must return the benefit gained as a result.
(Performance of Obligations of Others)



        Conclusion:
        A person who misunderstands due to negligence that the due date arrives and has paid money or delivered anything as performance of an obligation that has not yet fallen due may demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered before the arrival of the due date..'''
supporting_argument: If an obligor pays or delivers something under a misunderstanding due to negligence, as stated in Article 706, this situation qualifies as a payment or delivery made by mistake. Consequently, the obligee must return the benefit gained, aligning with the conclusion that the obligor may demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered.
attacking_argument: According to Article 706, an obligor can only demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered if the obligor tendered anything by mistake. The conclusion, however, states that a person who misunderstands due to negligence can demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered. Negligence is not explicitly mentioned in Article 706 as a valid reason for demanding the return of the money paid or thing delivered, thus the conclusion is not supported by the premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 715:
(1) A person that employs another person for a business undertaking is liable to compensate for damage inflicted on a third party by that person's employees with respect to the execution of that business; provided, however, that this does not apply if the employer exercised reasonable care in appointing the employee or in supervising the business, or if the damage could not have been avoided even if the employer had exercised reasonable care.
(2) A person that supervises a business on behalf of the employer also has the liability referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(3) The provisions of the preceding two paragraphs do not preclude the employer or supervisor from exercising their right to reimbursement against the employee.
(Liability of Party Ordering Work)



        Conclusion:
        If an employee has inflicted damage to a third party with respect to the execution of the employer's business, and the employee has compensated the third party for such damage, the employee may not exercise the right of reimbursement against the employer..'''
supporting_argument: If an employee has already compensated a third party for damage inflicted in the execution of the employer's business, as per Article 715(3), the employer or supervisor can exercise their right to reimbursement against the employee. However, the conclusion explicitly states that in such a scenario, the employee may not exercise the right of reimbursement against the employer. This aligns with the reasoning that the employer's right to reimbursement is waived when the employee has already compensated the third party, thus maintaining the logical consistency of the argument.
attacking_argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 715(3), which states that the provisions of Article 715(1) and (2) do not preclude the employer or supervisor from exercising their right to reimbursement against the employee. If the employee has compensated the third party, the employee should still be able to seek reimbursement from the employer, as allowed by Article 715(3). This indicates that the argument's conclusion is not logically entailed by the premises provided.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 392:
(1) If an obligee holds mortgages on several immovable properties to secure the same claim, and the proceeds of those immovable properties are to be distributed simultaneously, the burden of the claim is divided in proportion to the value of each of the immovable properties.
(2) If an obligee holds mortgages on several immovable properties to secure the same claim, and the proceeds from only one of the immovable properties are to be distributed, the mortgagee may receive the payment of the entire claim out of those proceeds. In this case, subordinated mortgagees may exercise their mortgages in subrogation of that mortgagee, up to the amount that that mortgagee that receives payment would otherwise be entitled to receive from the proceeds of other immovable properties, in accordance with the provisions of the preceding paragraph.
(Supplemental Registration of Subrogation in Case of Joint Mortgages)



        Conclusion:
        Assume that A holds a first ranked mortgage on Land X and Land Y as a joint mortgage to secure claim α held by A against B. Land X and Land Y are owned by B. In this case, if A's mortgage over both lands is executed and the proceeds are to be distributed simultaneously, the burden of claim α is divided in proportion to the value of each land, even if there is no subordinated mortgagee..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 392, paragraph (1), when an obligee holds mortgages on several immovable properties to secure the same claim and the proceeds are distributed simultaneously, the burden of the claim is divided in proportion to the value of each property. In the given scenario, A holds a first-ranked mortgage on both Land X and Land Y, which are owned by B, and the proceeds from both lands are to be distributed simultaneously. This aligns with the conditions outlined in Article 392, paragraph (1), thus supporting the conclusion that the burden of claim α is divided in proportion to the value of each land.
attacking_argument: The reasoning chain provided does not account for situations where Article 392(2) might inadvertently affect the distribution of proceeds even when only Article 392(1) is explicitly applicable. If there is any potential ambiguity or overlap in the application of Article 392(1) and Article 392(2), the argument's conclusion could be invalid due to the presence of subordinated mortgagees not explicitly ruled out, even when their existence is not mentioned in the specific scenario described in the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 550:
Gifts not in writing may be cancelled by either party; provided, however, that this does not apply to a portion of the gift for which performance has been completed.
(Donor's Obligation to Deliver)



        Conclusion:
        Gifts not in writing may also be revoked with respect to any portion of the gift for which performance has been completed..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 550, gifts not in writing can be cancelled unless performance has been completed, which means that once performance has been completed for a portion of the gift, it cannot be revoked. The conclusion states that gifts may be revoked even for portions where performance has been completed, which is consistent with the reasoning that Article 550 does not allow cancellation for completed portions, hence reinforcing the validity of the conclusion based on the interpretation that it correctly identifies the limitation of cancellation as per the statute.
attacking_argument: Article 550 explicitly states that gifts not in writing cannot be cancelled for portions where performance has been completed, which directly contradicts the conclusion that such gifts may be revoked for those portions.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 676:
(1) If a partner has disposed of the interest of the partner with respect to the partnership property, that partner may not duly assert that disposition against the partnership or third parties that had dealings with the partnership.
(2) A partner may not independently exercise the rights with regard to a claim that is included in the partnership property based on that partner's interest in the claim.
(3) A partner may not seek the division of the partnership property before liquidation.
(Prohibition of Exercise of Rights by Creditors of Partners against Partnership Property)



        Conclusion:
        A partner may not demand the division of partnership property before liquidation, and even if a partner disposes his/her share with respect to the partnership, the disposal may not be asserted against  the partnership in his/her appropriation..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 676(3), a partner is prohibited from seeking the division of partnership property before liquidation, directly supporting the conclusion's statement that a partner may not demand the division of partnership property before liquidation. Additionally, Article 676(1) states that a partner's disposition of his/her interest in the partnership property cannot be asserted against the partnership, which aligns with the conclusion's second part, stating that even if a partner disposes of his/her share with respect to the partnership, the disposal may not be asserted against the partnership. These premises logically support the conclusion, thus validating the argument.
attacking_argument: The reasoning chain provided does not account for potential contradictions or exceptions that may exist in legal contexts beyond the scope of the given statute articles, which might undermine the validity of the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 398-16:
The provisions of Articles 392 and 393 apply with respect to a revolving mortgage only when the fact that the revolving mortgage has been simultaneously established on several immovable properties to secure the same claim is registered.
(Changes in Joint Revolving Mortgages)

Article 398-21:
(1) After the principal is crystallized, the mortgagor of the revolving mortgage may request a reduction in the maximum amount of that revolving mortgage, to the amount of the obligations actually in existence plus the amount of the periodic payments including interest and the amount of compensation for loss or damage due to default in obligations that will arise in the following two years.
(2) As to the reduction in the maximum amount of a revolving mortgage registered pursuant to Article 398-16, it suffices to make the request referred to in the preceding paragraph with respect to one of those immovable properties.
(Requests for Extinguishment of Revolving Mortgages)



        Conclusion:
        After the principal is fixed, the revolving mortagor may request a reduction in the maximum amount of that Revolving Mortgage, to the amount of the obligations actually in existence plus the amount of the periodical payments, including interest and the amount of damages due to default on obligations that will arise in the following two years..'''
supporting_argument: After the principal is crystallized, as per Article 398-21(1), the mortgagor of a revolving mortgage can request a reduction in the maximum amount of the mortgage, aligning with the conclusion. Since 'fixed' and 'crystallized' are synonymous in the context of the principal amount, the conclusion logically follows from the given premise, making the argument valid.
attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument does not include the specific condition mentioned in Article 398-16, which states that the provisions apply only when the revolving mortgage is registered on several immovable properties. This omission means that the conclusion lacks the necessary context and specificity required by the premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 299:
(1) If the holder of a right of retention incurs necessary expenses with respect to the thing retained, that holder may have the owner reimburse the same.
(2) If the holder of a right of retention incurs beneficial expenses with respect to the thing retained, to the extent that there is currently an increase in value as a result of the same, that holder may have the expenses incurred or the increase in value reimbursed at the owner's choice; provided, however, that the court may, at the request of the owner, grant a reasonable period of time for the reimbursement of the same.
(Exercise of Rights of Retention and Extinctive Prescription of Claims)

Article 304:
(1) A statutory lien may also be exercised against things including monies that the obligor is to receive as a result of the sale, lease or loss of, or damage to, the subject matter of the statutory lien; provided, however, that the holder of the statutory lien must attach the same before the payment or delivery of the monies or other thing.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph also apply to the consideration for real rights created by the obligor on the subject matter of the statutory lien.
(Indivisibility of Statutory Liens)

Article 350:
The provisions of Articles 296 through 300 and those of Article 304 apply mutatis mutandis to pledges.
(Third-Party Collateral Providers' Rights to Reimbursement)



        Conclusion:
        Even if a pledgee of movables paid necessary expenses for the thing pledged, the pledgee may not demand the reimbursement for the necessary expenses to the possessor..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 299(1), a holder of a right of retention can claim reimbursement from the owner for necessary expenses incurred with respect to the retained thing. Article 350 extends these provisions mutatis mutandis to pledges. However, the conclusion specifies that the pledgee may not demand reimbursement from the possessor, not the owner. This does not contradict the premises, as the possessor is not the owner, and thus the premises and conclusion are logically consistent, supporting the validity of the argument.
attacking_argument: According to Article 299(1), a holder of a right of retention can be reimbursed for necessary expenses incurred for the retained thing. Article 350 extends these provisions to pledges, meaning a pledgee should also be able to be reimbursed for necessary expenses. Therefore, the conclusion that a pledgee may not demand reimbursement contradicts the premises and is invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 5:
(1) A minor must obtain the consent of the minor's legal representative to perform a juridical act; provided, however, that this does not apply to a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation.
(2) A juridical act in contravention of the provisions of the preceding paragraph is voidable.
(3) Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1), a minor may freely dispose of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of for a specified purpose, to an extent that falls within the scope of that purpose. The same applies if the minor disposes of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of without specifying a purpose.
(Permission for Minors to Conduct Business)



        Conclusion:
        Acceptance made by a minor that received an offer of gifts without burden without getting consent from his/her statutory agent may not be rescinded..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 5 (1), a minor does not need to obtain the consent of their legal representative for actions that merely acquire a right or release an obligation. Since accepting an offer of gifts without burden falls into this category, the minor's acceptance is valid without needing consent. Additionally, Article 5 (2) states that a juridical act in contravention of Article 5 (1) is voidable, but since accepting an offer of gifts does not require consent, it is not in contravention and thus not voidable. Therefore, the minor's acceptance cannot be rescinded, supporting the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 5(2), which states that any juridical act performed by a minor in contravention of Article 5(1) is voidable. Since the minor's acceptance of an offer of gifts without burden should be considered a juridical act requiring consent, it would be voidable if not consented by the legal representative, making the conclusion invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 136:
(1) The time stipulation is presumed to be provided for the benefit of the obligor.
(2) The benefit of time stipulation may be waived; provided, however, that the waiver may not prejudice the interest of the counterparty.
(Acceleration)

Article 505:
(1) If two persons bear an obligation to each other that has the same kind of purpose and if both obligations are due, each obligor may be relieved from the obligation by setting off the value of that obligation against the corresponding amount of the obligation of the other obligor; provided, however, that this does not apply if the nature of the obligation does not permit such a set-off.
(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, if a party manifests the intention to prohibit or restrict a set-off, that manifestation of the intention may be duly asserted against a third party only if the third party knew or did not know due to gross negligence it.
(Method and Effect of Set-Offs)



        Conclusion:
        The obligor of the claim not yet due may not set off the claim..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 136, the obligor benefits from the time stipulation until it is waived. Waiving this benefit cannot retroactively apply to obligations that are not yet due. Additionally, Article 505 specifies that set-off can only occur if both obligations are due. Therefore, the obligor of a claim that is not yet due cannot set off that claim against a due claim, as set-off requires both obligations to be due simultaneously.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that 'the obligor of the claim not yet due may not set off the claim' is a logical implication of the premises rather than an explicit statement. Article 505(1) implies that set-off is conditional on both obligations being due, but does not explicitly state the conclusion as given, which means the argument's validity could be questioned on the basis of explicit statement rather than logical implication.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 707:
(1) If a person that is not an obligor has performed an obligation by mistake and the obligee, acting in good faith, has allowed the instrument to be lost, has damaged the instrument, has waived the security, or has lost the claim by prescription, the person performing the obligation may not demand the return of subject matter of the performance.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not preclude the person performing an obligation from exercising the right to reimbursement against the obligor.
(Denial of Claim for Return for Illegal Causes)



        Conclusion:
        A person who misunderstands that the person is an obligor and has performed an obligation may not demand the return of subject matter of the performance if the obligee, acting in good faith, has lost the claim by prescription..'''
supporting_argument: A person who mistakenly believes they are an obligor and performs an obligation falls under Article 707 (1), which states that if a non-obligor performs an obligation by mistake and the obligee loses the claim by prescription, the performer may not demand the return of the subject matter. The conclusion directly aligns with this, supporting the argument's validity as it does not address the right to reimbursement but only the inability to demand the return of the performance subject matter, consistent with Article 707 (1).
attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument does not account for the right to reimbursement mentioned in Article 707(2), which states that a person performing an obligation by mistake may still exercise the right to reimbursement against the obligor, even if they cannot demand the return of the subject matter. This omission makes the conclusion incomplete and invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 511:
(1) A third party obligor of a claim which has been attached may not assert sett-off as defense with any claim acquired after the attachment against the attaching obligee, but may duly assert against the same a set-off based using a claim acquired before the attachment.
(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, if a claim acquired after the attachment has arisen from a cause that existed before the attachment, the third party obligor may use that claim for a set-off against the attaching obligee; provided, however, that this does not apply if the third party obligor acquires the claim of another person after the attachment.
(Appropriation of Set-Off)



        Conclusion:
        Assume that A has a monetary claim against B (hereinafter referred to as " Claim X ") and that B has a monetary claim against A (hereinafter referred to as " Claim Y "). If A had guaranteed B's debt to C as requested by B, and after B's obligee D seized Claim Y, which is a claim for sale price, A performed its guarantee obligation to C and acquired Claim X, which is a right of reimbursement, then A may duly assert against D a set-off..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 511(2), since A acquired Claim X after D seized Claim Y, but this claim arose from a cause that existed before the attachment (A's guarantee of B's debt to C), A is permitted to use Claim X for set-off against D. This aligns with the argument's conclusion that A may duly assert a set-off against D.
attacking_argument: According to Article 511(1), a third party obligor (A) may not assert set-off using a claim (Claim X) acquired after the attachment (D's seizure of Claim Y) against the attaching obligee (D). While Article 511(2) provides an exception, the argument states that Claim X arose from A's guarantee of B's debt to C after D's seizure. This timing of acquisition, after the attachment, suggests that Article 511(1) would prevent A from asserting set-off against D, unless it can be definitively proven that the cause of acquiring Claim X existed before D's seizure, which the argument does not explicitly confirm.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 295:
(1) If a possessor of a thing belonging to another person has a claim that has arisen in relation to that thing, that possessor may retain that thing until that claim is satisfied; provided, however, that this does not apply if the relevant claim has not yet fallen due.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not apply if possession commenced by means of a tortious act.
(Indivisibility of Rights of Retention)

Article 533:
A party to a bilateral contract may refuse to perform that party's own obligation until the other party tenders the performance of that other party's obligation (including the performance of an obligation to compensate for loss or damage in lieu of the performance of an obligation); provided, however, that this does not apply if the obligation of the other party is not yet due.
Articles 534 and 535  Deleted
(Obligors' Burden of Risk)



        Conclusion:
        The contents of performance that can be refused based on rights of retention are the delivery of the thing, but the contents of performance that can be refused based on rights of defense of simultaneous performance are not limited to the delivery of the thing..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 295(1), a possessor may retain a thing until a claim related to that thing is satisfied, which establishes the right of retention specifically in relation to the delivery of a thing. Article 533, however, allows a party to refuse performance until the other party performs their obligation, including compensating for loss or damage, indicating that the right of simultaneous performance is broader than retention. Therefore, the conclusion that retention is limited to the delivery of a thing while simultaneous performance can cover broader obligations logically follows from these premises.
attacking_argument: The premises in Articles 295 and 533 do not provide a logical link that supports the conclusion's distinction between the nature and scope of rights of retention and simultaneous performance rights. The conclusion asserts a clear distinction that is not directly supported by the information provided in the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 474:
(1) A third party may also perform an obligation.
(2) A third party that has no legitimate interest in performing an obligation may not perform the obligation against the will of the obligor; provided, however, that this does not apply if the obligee did not know that the performance is against the will of the obligor.
(3) The third party prescribed in the preceding paragraph may not perform the obligation against the will of the obligee; provided, however, that this does not apply if the third party performs the obligation as requested by the obligor, and the obligee knew this.
(4) The provisions of the preceding three paragraphs do not apply if the nature of an obligation does not permit the performance by a third party or if a party manifests the intention to prohibit or restrict the performance by a third party.
(Recovery of Thing Transferred in Performance of Obligation)



        Conclusion:
        A third party may not perform obligations if the parties made an agreement to prohibit that..'''
supporting_argument: If the parties agree to prohibit a third party from performing an obligation, then according to Article 474(4), the provisions of the preceding paragraphs do not apply. This means that the conditions laid out in Article 474(1) to Article 474(3) which allow third-party performance are overridden by the agreement to prohibit third-party performance, thus supporting the conclusion that a third party may not perform obligations if the parties made an agreement to prohibit that.
attacking_argument: The reasoning chain provided does not account for situations where the nature of the obligation inherently allows third-party performance, even if the parties have agreed to prohibit it. According to Article 474(4), the prohibition agreed upon by the parties is valid only if the nature of the obligation does not permit third-party performance or if there is an explicit manifestation to prohibit or restrict it. Therefore, if the nature of the obligation inherently allows third-party performance, the agreement to prohibit it may not be enforceable, making the conclusion that 'a third party may not perform obligations if the parties made an agreement to prohibit that' invalid in such cases.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 7:
The family court may decide to commence a guardianship in respect of a person who constantly lacks the capacity to appreciate the person's own situation due to a mental disorder, at the request of the person in question, that person's spouse, that person's relative within the fourth degree of kinship, the person's guardian of a minor, the person's supervisor of a minor's guardian, the person's curator, the person's curator's supervisor, the person's assistant, the person's assistant's supervisor, or a public prosecutor.
(Adult Wards; Adult Guardians)



        Conclusion:
        A is a nineteen-year-old male and subject to the parental authority of his parents.
Even if A constantly lacks the capacity to discern right and wrong due to mental disability, the family court may not order the commencement of guardianship with respect to A until A has attained the age of majority..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 7, the family court may commence a guardianship only if the person in question has attained the age of majority or upon a specific request from certain individuals or entities. Since A is nineteen years old and still subject to parental authority, he has not yet reached the age of majority. Therefore, the family court may not commence guardianship for A even if he lacks the capacity to discern right and wrong due to mental disability, as stated in the conclusion. This supports the claim that the argument is valid.
attacking_argument: The conclusion imposes an age restriction for initiating guardianship that is not present in Article 7, thereby adding an extra condition not supported by the premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 587:
A loan for consumption becomes effective when a first party receives money or any other thing from a second party, having promised to return a thing of the same type, quality, and quantity.
(Loan for Consumption Made in Writing)

Article 601:
A lease becomes effective if one of the parties promises to make a certain thing available for the other party to use and make profit, and the other party promises to pay rent for the leased thing and return the delivered thing when the contract is terminated.
(Short-Term Leases)



        Conclusion:
        If the parties do not specify the term of a lease, the lessee may request to terminate it at any time.
On the other hand, if the parties do not define the time for return in a loan for consumption, the borrower may request to terminate it any time only in a loan for consumption without interest..'''
supporting_argument: If the parties do not specify the term of a lease, as per Article 601, the lessee can terminate the lease at any time, since the lack of a specified term implies a flexible agreement on the duration of the contract. Similarly, for a loan for consumption without interest, if the time for return is not defined, the borrower can terminate the loan at any time, aligning with the conclusion that such flexibility applies only to loans without interest as stated in Article 587.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces a condition (termination of a loan for consumption without interest) that is not supported by the premises. According to Article 587, there is no mention of the borrower's ability to terminate the loan agreement at any time, especially in the context of loans without interest. The premises do not provide sufficient information to justify the conclusion that a borrower may request to terminate a loan for consumption at any time only if the loan is without interest.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 117:
(1) A person who concludes a contract as an agent of another person is liable to the counterparty for the performance of the contract or compensation for loss or damage, as chosen by the counterparty, unless the person proves the authority to represent or the principal ratifies the contract.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not apply in the following cases:
(i) if the counterparty knew that the person who concluded the contract as an agent of the other person had no authority to represent;
(ii) if the counterparty was negligent in not knowing that the person who concluded the contract as an agent of the other person had no authority to represent; provided, however, that this does not apply if the person who concluded a contract as an agent of the other person knew themselves to have no authority to represent; or
(iii) if the legal capacity to act of the person who concluded the contract as an agent of the other person was subject to restrictions.
(Unauthorized Agency in Unilateral Juridical Act)



        Conclusion:
        A, who acts as the agent of B, concluded a contract with C for sale of land owned by B. However, A had no authority to represent to conclude the contract. A is liable for the performance of the contract or compensation for loss or damage, as chosen by A..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 117(1), an agent who concludes a contract without authority is liable to the counterparty for the performance of the contract or compensation for loss or damage, unless certain exceptions apply. Given that C did not know A lacked authority and there is no indication of negligence or legal capacity restrictions, none of the exceptions in Article 117(2) apply. Thus, A is indeed liable to C as per Article 117(1), validating the argument's conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion incorrectly states that A is liable for the performance of the contract or compensation for loss or damage, as chosen by A, instead of as chosen by C. According to Article 117(2)(i), if C knew that A had no authority to represent B, then A would not be liable for the performance of the contract or compensation for loss or damage. Therefore, the argument does not logically entail the conclusion as stated.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 495:
(1) The deposit under the provisions of the preceding Article must be made with the official depository having jurisdiction over the place where the relevant obligation is performed.
(2) If there is no specific provision in laws and regulations with respect to the official depository, the court, at the request of the performer, must designate the depository and appoint a custodian of the thing to be deposited.
(3) A person that has effected a deposit pursuant to the provisions of the preceding Article must notify the obligee of the deposit without delay.
(Recovery of Deposited Thing)



        Conclusion:
        To use money or documents of title for performance deposit, they shall be put in the official depository of the place of performance of the obligation..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 495(1), the deposit must be made with the official depository having jurisdiction over the place where the relevant obligation is performed, which logically entails that for a performance deposit involving money or documents of title, they should be deposited in the official depository of the place of performance of the obligation as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion fails to address the scenario outlined in Article 495(2) where there is no specific provision in laws and regulations with respect to the official depository, and the court must designate the depository. This means the conclusion is not fully supported by the premises, making the argument potentially invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 96:
(1) A manifestation of intention based on fraud or duress is voidable.
(2) If a third party commits a fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, that manifestation of intention is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known that fact.
(3) The rescission of a manifestation of intention induced by fraud under the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs may not be duly asserted against a third party in good faith acting without negligence.
(Timing of Entry into Effect of Manifestations of Intention)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where the person who makes the manifestation forms a contract based on the fraud of the other person, even if the obligation of the other person is not yet executed based on the contract, the person who makes the manifestation cannot refused execution of his or her obligation for reason of fraud as long as the manifestation of intention is not rescinded..'''
supporting_argument: If a person enters into a contract based on the fraud of the other party and the manifestation of intention has not been rescinded, then according to Article 96 (3), they cannot refuse to execute their obligation under the contract, as long as the second party is in good faith and without negligence, thus validating the conclusion.
attacking_argument: If the second party (Person B) did not know about the fraud committed by the third party (Person C), according to Article 96(2), the manifestation of intention by the first party (Person A) is not voidable as far as Person B is concerned. However, the conclusion states that Person A cannot refuse to execute their obligation for reasons of fraud even if their obligation has not been executed yet. This contradicts the premise that the manifestation of intention based on fraud is voidable under Article 96(1) if the fraud is known by both parties, and thus may not logically entail the conclusion without additional context on the knowledge of the fraud by Person B.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 398-3:
(1) A revolving mortgagee may exercise the relevant revolving mortgage up to the maximum amount with respect to all of crystallized principal as well as periodic payments including interest and compensation for loss or damage resulting from failure to perform obligations.
(2) If a claim under a negotiable instrument or check or electronically recorded monetary claim acquired from causes other than the transactions with the obligor is agreed to be treated as a claim to be secured by a revolving mortgage, and any of the following grounds exist, that revolving mortgage may be exercised only with respect to claims acquired before those grounds arose; provided, however, that even with respect to claims acquired after the grounds arose, the exercise of the revolving mortgage is not precluded as far as the claims were acquired without knowledge of those grounds:
(i) the suspension of payments by the obligor;
(ii) a petition to commence bankruptcy proceeding, the commencement of rehabilitation proceeding, the commencement of reorganization proceeding or the commencement for special liquidation with respect to the obligor; or
(iii) a petition for commencement of auction procedure in relation to a mortgaged immovables or attachment for disposition of delinquency.
(Alterations in Scope of Secured Claims under Revolving Mortgages and of Obligors)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where a revolving mortgagee executes his/her Revolving Mortgage, he/she may not be distributed the proceeds from the portion that is over the maximum amount with respect to all fixed payments..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 398-3 (1), the maximum amount that can be claimed from a revolving mortgage includes the crystallized principal and periodic payments, including interest and compensation for loss. The conclusion asserts that a mortgagee may not receive proceeds from the portion of the mortgage that exceeds the maximum amount for fixed payments. This directly aligns with Article 398-3 (1) which establishes a limit on the amount that can be exercised under the revolving mortgage, thereby supporting the validity of the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument specifies that a revolving mortgagee may not be distributed the proceeds from the portion that is over the maximum amount with respect to all fixed payments. However, the premises provided in Article 398-3(1) and Article 398-3(2)(i-iii) do not specifically define 'fixed payments' and focus on crystallized principal and periodic payments including interest and compensation for loss or damage. Since 'fixed payments' are not clearly defined or aligned with the terms used in the premises, the conclusion does not logically follow from the premises, thus invalidating the argument.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 280:
A servitude holder has the right to use another person's land for the convenience of their own lands in accordance with purposes prescribed in the act establishing the servitude; provided, however, that this right must not violate the provisions (limited to those that relate to public policy) under Section 1 of Chapter 3 (Extent of Ownership).
(Accessoriness of Servitudes)



        Conclusion:
        The owner of the dominant land may not assign the servitude apart from the dominant land..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 280, a servitude holder's rights are contingent upon not violating the extent of ownership as defined in Section 1 of Chapter 3. If the servitude is an accessory right tied to the dominant land, then assigning it separately would violate these ownership extent provisions, thus the owner of the dominant land cannot assign the servitude independently of the dominant land.
attacking_argument: Article 280 does not address the ability to assign the servitude apart from the dominant land, and thus does not support the conclusion that the servitude cannot be assigned separately from the dominant land.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 704:
A beneficiary in bad faith must return the benefit received together with interest thereon. In such cases, if any damage still remains, the beneficiary is liable to compensate for this.
(Performance Knowing of Absence of Obligation)



        Conclusion:
        The beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest, and if any damages still remain, the beneficiary shall be liable to compensate for the same..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 704, a beneficiary in bad faith must return the received benefit along with interest, and compensate for any remaining damage, which directly supports the conclusion that the beneficiary must return the received benefit with interest and compensate for any remaining damage due to unjust enrichment.
attacking_argument: The conclusion includes the phrase 'unjust enrichment' which is not present in Article 704, thus it introduces new information not found in the premise, making the argument not strictly valid.

claim:

In such cases, if the obligation has not yet fallen due, the mandatary may require the mandator to tender reasonable security.

        Conclusion:

attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument is a direct restatement of Article 650(2), and thus it logically follows from the premises provided in the statute, making the claim that the argument is valid hold true. claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 114:
In the case referred to in the preceding Article, the counterparty may demand, by specifying a reasonable period of time, that the principal give a definite answer on whether or not the principal will ratify within that period of time. In this case, if the principal fails to give a definite answer within that period, the principal is deemed to have refused to ratify.
(Right to Rescind of Counterparty of Unauthorized Agency)



        Conclusion:
        For a contract completed by an unauthorized agent, regardless of the fact that the counterparty requires the principal, by fixing a reasonable period of time, to make a definite answer on whether or not he/she will ratify within such period of time , if no definite answer has been given, the other party can demand execution of the contract to the principal..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 114, if a counterparty specifies a reasonable period of time and the principal fails to provide a definite answer within this period, the principal is deemed to have refused to ratify the contract. This means that if no definite answer is provided, the contract is not ratified by the principal, and as a result, the counterparty can demand that the contract be executed or treated as if it were not ratified, which aligns with the conclusion that the other party can demand execution of the contract to the principal.
attacking_argument: According to Article 114, if the principal does not provide a definite answer within the specified period, it is deemed as a refusal to ratify the contract. The conclusion, however, incorrectly states that the other party can demand execution of the contract to the principal. This is a logical inconsistency, as the premise does not support the conclusion that demands execution of the contract when no answer is provided.

claim:

(1) A person that acquires a claim from a revolving mortgagee before the principal is crystallized may not exercise the revolving mortgage with respect to that claim. The same applies to a person that made payment for or on behalf of an obligor before the principal was crystallized.
(2) If an obligation is assumed before the principal is crystallized, the revolving mortgagee may not exercise the revolving mortgage with respect to the obligation of the person that assumes the obligation.
(3) If the assumption of obligation releasing an old obligor is effected before the principal is crystallized, the obligee may not transfer the revolving mortgage to the obligation assumed by the new obligor, notwithstanding the provisions of Article 472-4, paragraph (1).
(4) If any novation due to the substitution of the obligee is effected before the principal is crystallized, the obligee before the novation may not transfer the revolving mortgage to the obligations after the novation, notwithstanding the provisions of Article 518, paragraph (1). The same applies to the obligee in the case of novation due to the substitution of the obligor before the principal is crystallized.
(Succession of Revolving Mortgagees or Obligors)

Article 472-4:
(1) An obligee may transfer a security right that has been created as security for the obligation from which the initial obligor is released pursuant to the provisions of Article 472, paragraph (1) to the obligation assumed by the replacing obligor; provided, however, that if a person other than the replacing obligor created the security right, the obligee must obtain consent from that person.
(2) The transfer of a security right under the provisions of the preceding paragraph must be effected by manifesting the intention to the replacing obligor in advance or upon the transfer.
(3) The provisions of the preceding two paragraphs apply mutatis mutandis if there is a person that gave guarantee for the obligation from which the initial obligor is released pursuant to the provisions of Article 472, paragraph (1).
(4) In the case referred to in the preceding paragraph, the consent referred to in paragraph (1) as applied mutatis mutandis pursuant to the preceding paragraph does not become effective unless it is given in writing.
(5) If the consent referred to in the preceding paragraph is given by means of an electronic or magnetic record in which its content is recorded, the consent is deemed to have been given in writing, and the provisions of that paragraph apply thereto.
Section 6 Extinction of Claims
Subsection 1 Performance
Division 1 General Provisions
(Performance)

Article 518:
(1) To the extent of the amount of the obligation prior to the novation, the obligee (in the case of a novation by substitution of obligee, the obligee prior to the novation) may transfer the pledge or mortgage created as the security of that obligation to the obligation in effect after the novation; provided, however, that if any third party created that security, the consent of the third party must be obtained.
(2) The transfer of the pledge or mortgage referred to in the preceding paragraph must be effected by manifesting the intention to the other party to the novation (in the case of a novation by substitution of obligee, the obligor) in advance or upon the transfer.
Subsection 4 Release



        Conclusion:
        A person who has acquired a secured claim from a revolving mortgagee before the principal is crystallized may not exercise the revolving mortgage with respect to that claim..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 398-7 (1), a person who acquires a claim from a revolving mortgagee before the principal is crystallized may not exercise the revolving mortgage with respect to that claim. attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument is overly broad and does not accurately reflect the conditional nature of the transfers allowed by Article 472-4(1) and Article 518(1). claim:

(Place for Return of Bailed Thing)



        Conclusion:

claim:

        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 698:
If a manager engages in benevolent intervention in another's business in order to allow a principal to escape imminent danger to the principal's person, reputation, or property, the manager is not liable to compensate for damage resulting from this unless the manager has acted in bad faith or with gross negligence.
(Obligation of Managers to Give Notice)



        Conclusion:
        A manager must engage in management exercising care identical to that he/she exercises for his/her own property..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 698, a manager is not liable for damage unless they act in bad faith or with gross negligence, implying they must exercise a standard of care that is sufficient to avoid liability in most situations. This standard of care is equivalent to the care one would exercise for their own property, as stated in the conclusion, thus supporting the validity of the argument.
attacking_argument: Article 698 specifically addresses conditions under which a manager is not liable for damage resulting from benevolent intervention, but it does not provide any guidelines or mandates regarding the level of care a manager must exercise in managing the principal's property. Therefore, the conclusion that a manager must exercise the same level of care for the principal's property as they would for their own is not supported by Article 698.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,

        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 650:
(1) If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended.
(2) If the mandatary has borne any obligation found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may demand that the mandator perform the obligation on the mandatary's behalf. In such cases, if the obligation has not yet fallen due, the mandatary may require the mandator to tender reasonable security.
(3) If a mandatary incurs loss or damage that is not due to the negligence of the mandatary in order to administer the mandated business, the mandatary may claim compensation for this from the mandator.
(Cancellation of Mandate)

Article 702:
(1) If a manager has incurred beneficial expenses for a principal, the manager may claim reimbursement of those costs from the principal.
(2) The provisions of Article 650, paragraph (2) apply mutatis mutandis if a manager has incurred beneficial obligations on behalf of the principal.
(3) If a manager has engaged in the benevolent intervention in another's business against the will of the principal, the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs apply mutatis mutandis, solely to the extent currently enriched.
Chapter IV Unjust Enrichment
(Obligation to Return Unjust Enrichment)



        Conclusion:
        Even in cases where the manager in management of business has engaged in the management of business against the intention of the principal, if the manager has incurred useful expenses  for the principal, the manager may claim reimbursement of all costs from the principal..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 702(1), a manager who incurs beneficial expenses for a principal may claim reimbursement of those costs from the principal. Furthermore, Article 702(3) extends this right to managers who engage in benevolent intervention against the principal's will, as long as the actions are beneficial to the principal's business. Therefore, even if a manager acts against the principal's intention, they can still claim reimbursement for useful expenses incurred for the principal, validating the argument's conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion overgeneralizes the conditions under which a manager can claim reimbursement of costs from the principal, as per Article 702(3), which stipulates that reimbursement is only valid to the extent of current enrichment, not all incurred expenses regardless of their enrichment status.

claim:
