        Article 196:
(1) If a possessor returns a thing in the possession thereof, the possessor may have the person recovering the thing reimburse the possessor for the costs the possessor has paid for its preservation and other necessary expenses; provided, however, that if the possessor has acquired fruits, ordinary and necessary expenses are borne by the possessor.
(2) With respect to the costs paid for by a possessor to improve the thing in the possession thereof and other beneficial expenses, the possessor may have the person recovering the thing reimburse the possessor for either the costs the possessor has paid or the amount of the increased value, whichever the person recovering the thing chooses, but only if there is a current increase in value; provided, however, that with regard to a possessor in bad faith, the court may, at the request of the person recovering the thing, grant a reasonable period of time for the same.
(Possessory Actions)

Article 295:
(1) If a possessor of a thing belonging to another person has a claim that has arisen in relation to that thing, that possessor may retain that thing until that claim is satisfied; provided, however, that this does not apply if the relevant claim has not yet fallen due.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not apply if possession commenced by means of a tortious act.
(Indivisibility of Rights of Retention)

Article 608:
(1) If a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor, the lessee may immediately demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.
(2) If the lessee has incurred beneficial expenses with respect to the leased thing, the lessor must reimburse those expenses on termination of the lease in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2); provided, however, that the court may, at the lessor's request, grant a reasonable period of time for the reimbursement of the same.
(Demand for Reduction of Rent Due to Decrease in Profits)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where a lessee of a building has exercised a right of retention to secure reimbursement of the beneficial expenses after the termination of the lease, the right of retention will be extinguished if the court grants a period of time for the reimbursement at the request of the lessor..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 608(2), a lessee may be entitled to reimbursement for beneficial expenses from the lessor upon termination of the lease. If the court, at the lessor's request, grants a reasonable period of time for reimbursement as per Article 608(2), the lessee's immediate need to retain the thing to secure the claim diminishes. Since the right of retention is contingent on the immediate satisfaction of the claim, as stated in Article 295(1), it logically follows that the right of retention will be extinguished if the court grants a period of time for reimbursement, as the claim is deferred rather than immediately satisfied.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that the right of retention will be extinguished if the court grants a period for reimbursement at the lessor's request cannot be logically derived from the given premises. Article 608 specifies conditions for reimbursement but does not mention the extinguishment of the right of retention, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 601:
A lease becomes effective if one of the parties promises to make a certain thing available for the other party to use and make profit, and the other party promises to pay rent for the leased thing and return the delivered thing when the contract is terminated.
(Short-Term Leases)

Article 606:
(1) A lessor assumes an obligation to effect repairs necessary for using and making profit of the leased thing; provided, however, that this does not apply if repairs are necessary due to any grounds attributable to the lessee.
(2) A lessee may not refuse if the lessor seeks to engage in an act that is necessary for the preservation of the leased thing.
(Act of Preservation against the Will of the Lessee)

Article 613:
(1) If a lessee lawfully subleases a leased thing, the sublessee is liable to perform an obligation based on the sublease directly to the lessor, to the extent of the scope of the lessee's obligation based on the lease between the lessor and the lessee. In such a case, advance payment of rent may not be duly asserted against the lessor.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not preclude the lessor from exercising rights against the lessee.
(3) If the lessee lawfully subleases a leased thing, the lessor may not duly assert against the sublessee the cancellation by agreement of the lease with the lessee; provided, however, that this does not apply if, at the time of the cancellation, the lessor has a right to cancel due to non-performance on the part of the lessee.
(Timing of Payment of Rent)



        Conclusion:
        A concluded the contract with B that A leases his/her two-storied building "X" at a charge of 500,000 yen a month, and delivered the building "X" to B.
After that, B concluded the contract with C that B subleases the building "X" at a charge of 500,000 yen a month with obtaining the approval of A, and delivered the building "X" to C.
After a while, C became unable to use the second story of the building "X" due to the leak caused by defect of the roof.
C may demand B to repair the defect of the roof of the building "X"..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 601, the lease between A and B is valid since A delivered the building 'X' to B, and B agreed to pay rent. As per Article 606(1), A, being the lessor, has the obligation to repair the building necessary for its use and profit-making, unless the repairs are due to B's fault. Since B subleased the building to C with A's approval, under Article 613(1), C's obligations are directly to A, but B's obligations to maintain the building remain. Therefore, if C cannot use the second story due to a roof defect, not caused by C, B can be demanded to repair the roof, as B is responsible for the maintenance of the building 'X'.
attacking_argument: According to Article 606(1), the lessor A is responsible for repairs necessary for the leased thing unless the repairs are due to grounds attributable to the lessee B. Since the leak in the roof is due to a defect and not caused by B, B does not have an obligation to repair the roof. Therefore, C's demand for repair of the roof from B is not supported by the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 715:
(1) A person that employs another person for a business undertaking is liable to compensate for damage inflicted on a third party by that person's employees with respect to the execution of that business; provided, however, that this does not apply if the employer exercised reasonable care in appointing the employee or in supervising the business, or if the damage could not have been avoided even if the employer had exercised reasonable care.
(2) A person that supervises a business on behalf of the employer also has the liability referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(3) The provisions of the preceding two paragraphs do not preclude the employer or supervisor from exercising their right to reimbursement against the employee.
(Liability of Party Ordering Work)



        Conclusion:
        The employer is released from his/her liability in cases when proof is provided that the employer made proper care regarding the appointment and supervision of the employee..'''
supporting_argument: If an employer can demonstrate that they have exercised reasonable care in the appointment and supervision of an employee, as per Article 715(1), they are exempt from liability for damages caused by that employee. This aligns directly with the conclusion that states the employer is released from liability under such circumstances.
attacking_argument: The conclusion states that the employer is released from liability if they prove proper care in appointing and supervising the employee, but Article 715(1) only specifies that the employer is not liable if they exercised reasonable care, not if they proved they did so. This introduces ambiguity because proving reasonable care requires additional evidence beyond what is stated in the article, and it's not clear if this evidence is part of the premises or needs to be assumed outside of them.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 185:
If it is assumed, due to the nature of the title, that a possessor does not have the intention to own, the nature of the possessor's possession does not change unless that possessor manifests the intention to own to the person that put the thing under that person's possession, or commences possession under a new title with an intention to own from that time.
(Presumption Regarding Nature of Possession)



        Conclusion:
        When B, who had been in possession of movable X by leasing them from their owner A, made an agreement with A to purchase X from A and transfer A's right of possession, B's possession is regarded as possession with the intention to own them..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 185, if a possessor starts to possess an item under a new title with the intention to own, the nature of their possession changes to reflect that intention. B's possession of movable X initially was by leasing, which indicates no intention to own. However, B's agreement to purchase X from A marks the commencement of a new title with an intention to own, thereby changing B's possession to be regarded as possession with the intention to own, as per Article 185.
attacking_argument: According to Article 185, B's possession of movable X should not change from leasing to owning unless B explicitly manifests the intention to own X to A or commences possession under a new title with an intention to own. The provided information does not indicate that B did either of these actions, which means the nature of B's possession should remain as leasing and not transition to owning. Therefore, the conclusion that B's possession is regarded as possession with the intention to own them may not be logically entailed by the premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 511:
(1) A third party obligor of a claim which has been attached may not assert sett-off as defense with any claim acquired after the attachment against the attaching obligee, but may duly assert against the same a set-off based using a claim acquired before the attachment.
(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, if a claim acquired after the attachment has arisen from a cause that existed before the attachment, the third party obligor may use that claim for a set-off against the attaching obligee; provided, however, that this does not apply if the third party obligor acquires the claim of another person after the attachment.
(Appropriation of Set-Off)



        Conclusion:
        If B who had been enjoined from making payment with respect to A's claim "X" against B acquires the claim "Y" against A, B may set off the claim "X" against the claim "Y"..'''
supporting_argument: If B acquires claim 'Y' against A after the attachment of claim 'X', and claim 'Y' arises from a cause that existed before the attachment of claim 'X', then B may set off claim 'X' against claim 'Y' as per Article 511(2). This directly supports the conclusion that B may set off claim 'X' against claim 'Y'.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that B may set off claim 'X' against claim 'Y' is not necessarily valid, as it does not account for the conditions specified in Article 511(2), which requires that the claim 'Y' must arise from a cause that existed before the attachment and B did not acquire it from another person after the attachment.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 105:
A legal representative may appoint a subagent on its own responsibility. In such a case, if there is a compelling reason to do so, the legal representative is only liable to the principal for the appointment and supervision of the subagent.
(Authority of Subagents)



        Conclusion:
        If a legal representative appoints a subagent due to a compelling reason, the legal representative is only liable to the principal for the appointment and supervision of the subagent..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 105, if a legal representative appoints a subagent due to a compelling reason, they are only liable to the principal for the appointment and supervision of the subagent. This directly supports the conclusion of the argument, which states the same, thus validating the argument's validity.
attacking_argument: The reasoning chain provided does not reveal any hidden assumptions or contradictions that would invalidate the argument. However, the absence of such contradictions does not necessarily mean the argument is valid without considering external factors not mentioned in Article 105, such as the definition of 'compelling reason' or the interpretation of 'liability' in broader legal contexts.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 565:
The provisions of the preceding three Articles apply mutatis mutandis if the right transferred by the seller to the buyer does not conform to the terms of the contract (including the case in which the seller fails to transfer part of a right that belongs to another person).
(Limitation on Period of Warranty with Respect to Kind or Quality of Subject Matter)

Article 566:
If the subject matter delivered by the seller to the buyer does not conform to the terms of the contract with respect to the kind or quality, and the buyer fails to notify the seller of the non-conformity within one year from the time when the buyer becomes aware of it, the buyer may not demand cure of the non-conformity of performance, demand a reduction of the price, claim compensation for loss or damage, or cancel the contract, on the grounds of the non-conformity; provided, however, that this does not apply if the seller knew or did not know due to gross negligence the non-conformity at the time of the delivery.
(Transfer of Risk for Loss of Subject Matter)



        Conclusion:
        There is a limitation period on pursuance of warranty if there is restriction due to superficies on the subject matter, but there is no restriction on pursuance of warranty if the seller's rights were revoked due to execution of the mortgage..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 566, if the subject matter does not conform to the terms of the contract and the buyer fails to notify the seller within one year, the buyer loses several rights. This aligns with the conclusion that states there is a limitation period for pursuing warranty unless the seller's rights were revoked due to mortgage execution, which is an exception mentioned in the reasoning chain and aligns with the conclusion's exception.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces specific conditions (restrictions due to superficies and the revocation of the seller's rights due to a mortgage) that are not directly addressed by the premises provided in the form of statute articles. Article 565 and Article 566 do not mention or provide any information about these specific conditions, making it impossible to logically infer that these conditions would not impose limitations on the pursuit of warranty.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 333:
Statutory liens may not be exercised against the movables that are the subject matter of the same after the obligors have delivered those movables to third party acquirers.
(Conflict between Statutory Liens and Pledges on Movables)



        Conclusion:
        Statutory liens for sale of movables may not be exercised with respect to the movable that are the subject matter of the same after the obligors have delivered those movables to third-party acquirers..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 333, statutory liens cannot be enforced against movables after they have been delivered to third-party acquirers by the obligors. Therefore, the conclusion that statutory liens for the sale of movables cannot be exercised with respect to movables delivered to third-party acquirers directly follows from Article 333, confirming the argument's validity.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces a specific condition,'statutory liens for sale of movables,' which is not present in the premise as stated in Article 333. The premise uses a more general term,'statutory liens,' and does not specify that it only applies to statutory liens for sale of movables.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 660:
(1) If a third party claiming rights with respect to the bailed thing has filed a lawsuit against the bailee, or has effected an attachment, provisional seizure, or provisional disposition, the bailee must notify the bailor of that fact without delay; provided, however, that this does not apply if the bailor already knows it.
(2) Even if a third party claims a right for the bailed thing, the bailee must return the bailed thing to the bailor unless the bailor gives instructions to the contrary; provided, however, that this does not apply if the bailee notifies the bailor in advance as referred to in the preceding paragraph or is not required to notify pursuant to the provisions of the proviso to that paragraph, and the bailee delivers the bailed thing to a third party based on a final and binding judgment (including anything that has the same effect as a final and binding judgment) ordering the delivery of the bailed thing to that third party.
(3) If the bailee is required to return the bailed thing to the bailor pursuant to the provisions of the preceding paragraph, the bailee is not liable to compensate any damage sustained by a third party due to the delivery of the bailed thing to the bailor.
(Compensation for Loss or Damage by Bailor)



        Conclusion:
        If a third party asserting rights with respect to the Thing deposited has brought a lawsuit against the depositary, the depositary must notify the depositor of that fact without delay..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 660(1), if a third party has brought a lawsuit against the bailee (depositary) with respect to the bailed thing (Thing deposited), the bailee (depositary) must notify the bailor (depositor) of that fact without delay. The conclusion mirrors this requirement, thus logically following from the premise and validating the argument.
attacking_argument: The conclusion uses the terms 'depositary' and 'depositor' instead of 'bailee' and 'bailor', respectively, which are synonymous in the context of bailment. However, Article 660(1) specifically requires that the bailee notify the bailor without delay only if the bailor does not already know about the lawsuit filed against the bailee. The conclusion does not specify whether the depositor already knows about the lawsuit, which makes it an incomplete representation of Article 660(1) and thus does not fully logically entail the conclusion as stated.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 593:
A loan for use becomes effective if one of the parties promises to deliver a certain thing, and the other party promises to return the thing when the contract is terminated after the other party gratuitously uses and makes profit of the borrowed thing.
(Lender's Right to Cancel Loan for Use Before the Receipt of Borrowed Thing)



        Conclusion:
        No contract of loan for use shall be effective unless it is made in writing..'''
supporting_argument: If a loan for use agreement is to be effective based on the promises between the parties as stated in Article 593, it can be inferred that such agreements should be formalized in writing to ensure clarity and enforceability, thus supporting the conclusion that no contract of loan for use shall be effective unless it is made in writing.
attacking_argument: According to Article 593, a loan for use contract becomes effective based solely on verbal promises between the parties, without the requirement of a written contract. This directly contradicts the conclusion which states that no contract of loan for use shall be effective unless it is made in writing. Therefore, the conclusion cannot logically follow from the premise, invalidating the claim that the argument is valid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 97:
(1) A manifestation of intention becomes effective at the time notice thereof reaches the other party.
(2) If the other party prevents notice of a manifestation of intention from reaching them without a legitimate reason, the notice is deemed to have reached that party at the time it would have normally reached them.
(3) The effect of a manifestation of intention is not impaired even if the person making it dies, loses mental capacity, or becomes subject to restrictions on their legal capacity to act after having sent the notice.
(Manifestation of Intention by Public Notice)



        Conclusion:
        A died after sending B a notice to cancel the contract, and the notice subsequently reached B. In this case, the effect of A's manifestation of intention to cancel is not impaired..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 97 (3), since A sent the notice to cancel the contract before dying, and the notice subsequently reached B, the effect of A's manifestation of intention to cancel the contract is not impaired by A's death, as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: According to Article 97 (3), the effect of a manifestation of intention is not impaired only in terms of the notice being valid and reaching the other party. However, if we consider the 'effect' to also include the person's ability to enforce or take further actions based on the notice, A's death after sending the notice could be seen as impairing the broader effect of the manifestation of intention, since A can no longer enforce or take further actions due to their death.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 550:
Gifts not in writing may be cancelled by either party; provided, however, that this does not apply to a portion of the gift for which performance has been completed.
(Donor's Obligation to Deliver)



        Conclusion:
        The donee may not cancel the gift with respect to the portion for which performance has not been completed, even if the gift is not made in writing..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 550, gifts not made in writing can be cancelled by either party, except for the portion of the gift where performance has been completed. Therefore, the donee cannot cancel the gift with respect to the portion for which performance has been completed, which aligns with the conclusion that the donee may not cancel the gift with respect to the portion for which performance has not been completed, even if the gift is not made in writing, as long as it does not contradict the exception for completed portions.
attacking_argument: According to Article 550, gifts not made in writing can be cancelled by either party, except for the portion for which performance has been completed. This means that the donee has the right to cancel the gift for the portion of the gift for which performance has not been completed. However, the conclusion states that the donee cannot cancel the gift for the portion for which performance has not been completed. This directly contradicts Article 550, thus the argument is invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 196:
(1) If a possessor returns a thing in the possession thereof, the possessor may have the person recovering the thing reimburse the possessor for the costs the possessor has paid for its preservation and other necessary expenses; provided, however, that if the possessor has acquired fruits, ordinary and necessary expenses are borne by the possessor.
(2) With respect to the costs paid for by a possessor to improve the thing in the possession thereof and other beneficial expenses, the possessor may have the person recovering the thing reimburse the possessor for either the costs the possessor has paid or the amount of the increased value, whichever the person recovering the thing chooses, but only if there is a current increase in value; provided, however, that with regard to a possessor in bad faith, the court may, at the request of the person recovering the thing, grant a reasonable period of time for the same.
(Possessory Actions)

Article 583:
(1) A seller may not effect redemption unless the seller provides the price and the costs of the contract within the period provided for in Article 580.
(2) If a buyer or subsequent acquirer incurs expenses with respect to immovables, the seller must reimburse those expenses in accordance with the provisions of Article 196; provided, however, that with respect to beneficial expenses, the court may, at the seller's request, grant a reasonable period of time for the reimbursement.
(Sale of Co-Ownership Interest with Special Agreements on Redemption)

Article 595:
(1) The borrower bears the ordinarily necessary expenses of borrowed thing.
(2) The provisions of Article 583, paragraph (2) apply mutatis mutandis to costs other than the ordinarily necessary expenses referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(Lender's Obligation to Deliver)

Article 608:
(1) If a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor, the lessee may immediately demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.
(2) If the lessee has incurred beneficial expenses with respect to the leased thing, the lessor must reimburse those expenses on termination of the lease in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2); provided, however, that the court may, at the lessor's request, grant a reasonable period of time for the reimbursement of the same.
(Demand for Reduction of Rent Due to Decrease in Profits)



        Conclusion:
        The borrower shall bear the ordinarily necessary costs of borrowed Things.
The lessee shall not bear the ordinarily necessary costs of leased Things..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 595, paragraph (1), the borrower bears the ordinarily necessary expenses of the borrowed thing, which directly supports the first part of the conclusion stating that the borrower shall bear the ordinarily necessary costs of borrowed things. Additionally, Article 608, paragraph (1), indicates that the lessee does not bear the ordinarily necessary expenses of the leased thing, but instead, the lessor does, supporting the second part of the conclusion that the lessee shall not bear the ordinarily necessary costs of leased things. Thus, the conclusion logically follows from the premises, making the argument valid.
attacking_argument: According to Article 608(1), a lessee may demand immediate reimbursement from the lessor for necessary expenses incurred for the leased thing. However, the conclusion states that the lessee shall not bear the ordinarily necessary costs of leased things, which contradicts the premise that the lessee is supposed to be reimbursed for these expenses.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 364:
The creation of a pledge over a claim (including a pledge over a claim which has not yet arisen) may not be duly asserted against a third party obligor and other third parties unless notice of the creation of the pledge is given to that third party obligor in accordance with the provisions of Article 467, or unless that third party obligors gives consent to the same.

Article 467:
(1) The assignment of a claim (including the assignment of a claim that is yet to arise) may not be duly asserted against the applicable obligor or any other third party, unless the assignor gives notice thereof to the obligor or the obligor has consented to the same.
(2) Notice or consent as referred to in the preceding paragraph may not be duly asserted against a third party other than the obligor unless the notice or the consent is made using an instrument bearing a certified date.
(Defense of Obligor upon Assignment of Claim)



        Conclusion:
        In cases of pledges over nominative claims, if there is an instrument for the claim, the pledge establishment does not take effect unless the instrument is delivered..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 364 and Article 467(1), the establishment of a pledge over a nominative claim, which often requires an instrument like a promissory note, cannot be asserted against third parties unless proper notice is given to the obligor. Furthermore, Article 467(2) states that such notice must be made using an instrument bearing a certified date to be valid against third parties. Therefore, if there is an instrument for the claim, the pledge establishment does not take effect unless the instrument is delivered, ensuring compliance with the legal requirement for notice.
attacking_argument: The conclusion introduces a requirement that the premises do not address, specifically the necessity of delivering an instrument for the pledge establishment to take effect, which is not mentioned in either Article 364 or Article 467.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 718:
(1) A possessor of an animal is liable to compensate for damage that the animal inflicts on another person; provided, however, that this does not apply if the possessor managed the animal while exercising reasonable care according to the kind and nature of the animal.
(2) A person who manages an animal on behalf of a possessor also assumes the liability referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(Liability of Joint Tortfeasors)



        Conclusion:
        A possessor of an animal shall not be liable to compensate for the damages that the animal has inflicted on others if he/she managed the animal with reasonable care according to the kind and nature of the animal..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 718(1), a possessor of an animal is exempt from liability if they managed the animal with reasonable care, which directly supports the conclusion that a possessor shall not be liable if they managed the animal with reasonable care, as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not account for the potential liability introduced by Article 718(2), where a person managing the animal on behalf of the possessor also assumes the liability, potentially leading to the possessor still being liable even if they managed the animal with reasonable care themselves.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 124:
(1) The ratification of a voidable act does not become effective unless it is made after the circumstances that made the act voidable cease to exist and the person ratifying the act becomes aware of the right to rescind it.
(2) In the following cases, the ratification referred to in the preceding paragraph is not required to be made after the circumstances that made the act voidable cease to exist:
(i) if a legal representative or a curator or assistant of a person with qualified legal capacity ratifies the act; or
(ii) if a person with qualified legal capacity (excluding an adult ward) makes the ratification with the consent of a legal representative, curator or assistant.
(Statutory Ratification)

Article 126:
The right to rescind an act is extinguished by the operation of the prescription if it is not exercised within five years from the time when it becomes possible to ratify the act. The same applies if 20 years have passed from the time of the act.
Section 5 Conditions and Time Limits
(Effect of Fulfillment of Conditions)



        Conclusion:
        The period of the extinctive prescription of the right to rescind about the act performed by an adult ward commences from the time of becoming a person with capacity to act..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 124(2), an adult ward's act can be ratified immediately by a legal representative, curator, or assistant without waiting for circumstances that made the act voidable to cease. Additionally, Article 126 specifies that the right to rescind an act is extinguished by prescription if not exercised within five years from the time ratification becomes possible. Therefore, for an adult ward, since ratification can occur immediately, the prescription period for rescinding the act begins from the moment the ward gains capacity to act.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that the period of extinctive prescription for adult wards starts from the time of becoming a person with capacity to act contradicts Article 124(1), which requires that the ratification of a voidable act must occur after the circumstances that made the act voidable cease to exist and the person becomes aware of the right to rescind it. This means the prescription period cannot start immediately upon becoming a person with capacity to act, as it must wait for the cessation of circumstances and awareness of the right to rescind.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 415:
(1) If an obligor fails to perform consistent with the purpose of the obligation or the performance of an obligation is impossible, the obligee may claim compensation for loss or damage arising from the failure; provided, however, that this does not apply if the failure to perform the obligation is due to grounds not attributable to the obligor in light of the contract or other sources of obligation and the common sense in the transaction.
(2) If the obligee is entitled to claim compensation for loss or damage pursuant to the provisions of the preceding paragraph, and any of the following cases applies, the obligee may claim compensation for loss or damage in lieu of the performance of the obligation:
(i) the performance of the obligation is impossible;
(ii) the obligor manifests the intention to refuse to perform the obligation; or
(iii) the obligation has arisen from a contract, and the contract is cancelled or the obligee acquires the right to cancel the contract on the ground of the obligor's failure to perform the obligation.
(Scope of Compensation for Loss or Damage)

Article 559:
The provisions of this Section apply mutatis mutandis to contracts for value other than contracts for sale; provided, however, that this does not apply when it is not permitted by the nature of the contract for value.
Subsection 2 Effect of Sale
(Seller's Obligation for Satisfaction of Requirements for Perfection of Transfer of Rights)

Article 564:
The provisions of the preceding two Articles do not preclude the buyer from claiming compensation for loss or damage pursuant to the provisions of Article 415 or exercising the right to cancel pursuant to the provisions of Articles 541 and 542.
(Seller's Warranty in Case of Non-Conformity of Transferred Right to Terms of Contract)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where there is any defect in the subject matter of work performed, if the repair of the defect is impossible, the party ordering the work may cancel the contract..'''
supporting_argument: If there is a defect in the subject matter of work performed and the repair of the defect is impossible, the party ordering the work (as the obligee) can cancel the contract pursuant to Article 564, which allows for the exercise of the right to cancel the contract when the performance is impossible, as per the provisions stated in Article 415 and Article 559.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that the party ordering the work may cancel the contract in cases where the repair of a defect is impossible does not necessarily follow from the provided statutes because Article 559 specifies that the provisions of Article 415 may not apply if it is not permitted by the nature of the contract for value, leaving room for exceptions where the nature of the contract could exclude the application of Article 415.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 109:
(1) A person who indicates to a third party that the person granted certain authority to represent to another person is liable for an act performed between that other person and that third party within the scope of the authority to represent; provided, however, that this does not apply if the third party knew or did not know due to negligence that the other person has not been granted the authority to represent.
(2) If a person who indicates to a third party that the person granted authority to represent to another person is, pursuant to the provisions of the preceding paragraph, liable for acts performed by that other person in relation to the third party within the scope of the authority to represent, and the other person performs in relation to the third party an act beyond the scope of the authority to represent, the person who makes the indication is liable for that act only if the third party has reasonable grounds for believing that the other person has authority to represent in that act.
(Apparent Authority of Act Exceeding Authority)



        Conclusion:
        A person who manifested to third parties that he/she granted certain authority of agency to other person shall be relieved of liability for acts performed within the scope of such authority if the person makes allegations and shows proof that such third parties knew, or were negligent in not knowing, that such other person were not granted the authority of agency..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 109(1), a person who indicates to a third party that another person has certain authority to represent them is not liable for acts performed within the scope of that authority if the third party knew or was negligent in not knowing that the other person did not have the authority. The conclusion directly states that a person can be relieved of liability for acts performed within the scope of such authority if they can show proof that the third parties knew, or were negligent in not knowing, that the other person was not granted the authority. This alignment between the conclusion and Article 109(1) supports the validity of the claim that the premises logically entail the conclusion.
attacking_argument: According to Article 109(1), a person who indicates to a third party that another person has certain authority to represent them is liable for acts performed by that other person within the scope of the authority, provided the third party did not know due to negligence that the other person has not been granted the authority. The conclusion, however, states that the person making the indication can be relieved of liability if they can show that the third parties knew or were negligent in not knowing that the other person had not been granted the authority. Since Article 109(1) does not mention any relief from liability based on the third parties' knowledge or negligence, the conclusion does not logically follow from the premises provided.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 292:
If dominant land is co-owned by more than one person, and expiry of prescription period is postponed or prescription period is renewed in favor of one co-owner, the postponement of expiry of prescription period or the renewal of prescription period is also effective for the benefit of other co-owners.



        Conclusion:
        Even if there is an interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land, due to factors of the other co-owners, such extinctive prescription proceeds..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 292, if the prescription period is renewed or postponed for one co-owner, it is also effective for the other co-owners. Therefore, if one co-owner's prescription period is interrupted, this interruption acts as a renewal for all co-owners, ensuring that the prescription period for all is not extinguished until it is allowed to run uninterrupted for all. This supports the conclusion that extinctive prescription proceeds only if it is not prevented by the actions of all co-owners.
attacking_argument: Article 292 only discusses the postponement or renewal of the prescription period in favor of one co-owner, which does not logically entail the conclusion that an interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner would proceed for the other co-owners.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 494:
(1) In the following cases, a performer may deposit the subject matter of the performance with an official depository for the benefit of the obligee. In such a case, the claim is extinguished when the performer makes the deposit:
(i) the performer tenders the performance, and the obligee refuses to accept it; or
(ii) the obligee is unable to accept the performance.
(2) The preceding paragraph also applies if the performer is unable to ascertain the obligee; provided, however, that this does not apply if the performer is negligent in this respect.
(Method of Deposit)



        Conclusion:
        If the obligor is unable to ascertain the obligeethe obligor may deposit the subject-matter of the performance with an official deposit, regardless of any negligence on the part of the obligor..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 494(2), an obligor may deposit the subject matter of the performance with an official depository when they are unable to ascertain the obligee, provided they are not negligent. This aligns with part of the conclusion which states that the obligor may deposit the subject matter when unable to ascertain the obligee, but it specifies that the obligor must not be negligent, which is a critical condition omitted in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 494(2) as it states the obligor can deposit the subject matter regardless of negligence, while the article specifies that the deposit does not apply if the performer is negligent in ascertaining the obligee.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 162:
(1) A person that possesses the property of another for 20 years peacefully and openly with the intention to own it acquires ownership thereof.
(2) A person that possesses the property of another for 10 years peacefully and openly with an intention to own it acquires ownership thereof if the person was acting in good faith and was not negligent at the time when the possession started.
(Acquisitive Prescription of Property Rights Other Than Ownership)

Article 163:
A person that exercises a property right other than ownership peacefully and openly with the intention to do so on the person's own behalf acquires that right after the passage of 20 years or 10 years, according to the distinction provided for in the preceding Article.
(Renewal of Acquisitive Prescription Due to Discontinuation of Possession)



        Conclusion:
        The period required to acquire superficies by prescription is ten years, regardless of the subjective circumstances of the person who claims to acquire it..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 163, a person can acquire property rights other than ownership after 10 years if they possess the property peacefully and openly with the intention to do so on their own behalf. The conclusion states that the period required to acquire superficies by prescription is ten years, which aligns with Article 163's provision without specifying subjective conditions, making the argument valid.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that the period required to acquire superficies by prescription is ten years, regardless of subjective circumstances, contradicts Article 162(2), which states that the 10-year period for acquiring ownership applies only if the person was acting in good faith and was not negligent at the time possession started.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 266:
(1) The provisions of Articles 274 through 276 apply mutatis mutandis if the superficiary must pay periodical rent to the owners of the land.
(2) Beyond what is provided for in the preceding paragraph, provisions on leasehold apply mutatis mutandis to rent to the extent that application is not inconsistent with the nature of the same.
(Mutatis Mutandis Application of Provisions Regarding Neighboring Relationships)



        Conclusion:
        Free superficies may not be established..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 266(2), provisions on leasehold apply mutatis mutandis to rent, which suggests a relationship involving payment. Since the conclusion states that 'Free superficies may not be established,' and free superficies implies no payment, there is a logical connection between the application of leasehold provisions (which involve payment) and the restriction of free superficies. This implies that the argument's conclusion could be valid if we infer that the application of leasehold provisions, which require payment, contradicts the idea of free superficies, which involves no payment.
attacking_argument: The premises in Article 266 do not address the possibility of free superficies, as they only specify conditions under which certain leasehold provisions apply mutatis mutandis when periodical rent is involved. Therefore, the conclusion that 'Free superficies may not be established' is not supported by the given premises, as there is no direct or indirect evidence provided against the establishment of free superficies.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 9:
A juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable; provided, however, that this does not apply to the purchase of daily necessities or to any other act involved in day-to-day life.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Guardianship)



        Conclusion:
        If an adult ward acquires land by gift, the guardian of the adult ward may not rescind the gift..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 9, a juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable unless it involves daily necessities or day-to-day life activities. Since acquiring land by gift does not fall into these exempt categories, the act of acquiring land by gift is voidable. However, the conclusion asserts that the guardian may not rescind the gift, which implies a specific legal context where guardianship does not have the power to rescind gifts of land despite the general voidability of the act, thus logically entailing the conclusion.
attacking_argument: According to Article 9, a juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable unless it pertains to daily necessities or day-to-day life. Acquiring land by gift is not a daily necessity or a day-to-day activity, which means it should be voidable. Therefore, the guardian should be able to rescind the gift, contradicting the conclusion that the guardian cannot rescind the gift. This shows that the argument's conclusion does not logically follow from the premises, making the argument invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 439:
(1) If one of the joint and several obligors has a claim against the obligee and invokes a set-off, the claim is extinguished for the benefit of all joint and several obligors.
(2) Until the joint and several obligor that has the claim referred to in the preceding paragraph invokes a set-off, other joint and several obligors may refuse to perform the obligation to the obligee only to the extent of that joint and several obligor's share of the obligation.
(Merger with One of Joint and Several Obligors)

Article 441:
Except in cases prescribed in Articles 438, Article 439, paragraph (1), and the preceding Article, any circumstances which have arisen with respect to one of the joint and several obligors is not effective in relation to other joint and several obligors; provided, however, that if the obligee and one of the other joint and several obligors manifest a different intention, their intention prevails with respect to the effect in relation to the remaining other joint and several obligees.
(Right to Reimbursement among Joint and Several Obligors)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where B, C, and D assume obligations amount of 3,000,000 yen jointly and severally, and even if A releases C from the full of obligation, B and D assume obligations amount of 3,000,000 yen jointly and severally..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 441, unless specific conditions in Articles 438 or 439(1) apply, circumstances affecting one joint and several obligor, such as A releasing C from the obligation, do not affect the other obligors (B and D). Since A's release of C does not invoke a set-off as specified in Article 439(1), B and D remain liable for their share of the 3,000,000 yen obligation, thus supporting the conclusion that B and D assume the full obligation even after A's release of C.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that B and D still assume the obligation amount of 3,000,000 yen even after A releases C contradicts Article 441, which states that circumstances arising with respect to one of the obligors (such as A releasing C from the obligation) are not effective in relation to other obligors (B and D) unless there is a different intention manifest by the obligee and one of the other obligors.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 536:
(1) If the performance of an obligation becomes impossible due to grounds not attributable to either party, the obligee may refuse to perform counter-performance.
(2) If the performance of an obligation becomes impossible due to grounds attributable to the obligee, the obligee may not refuse to complete counter-performance. In such a case, if the obligor benefits from being released from that obligation, the obligor must reimburse the obligee for the benefit.
(Third Party Beneficiary Contract)



        Conclusion:
        (A) and (B) agreed that (A) sell the used bicycle which (A) owned (hereinafter referred to as P) to (B) on April 1 with the provision for the delivery on april 10 and the payment on April 20. (P) was lost due to reasons attributable to (B) on April 8. In such case, (b) may not refuse the payment when (A) claims the payment from (B) on April 20..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 536(2), since the bicycle was lost due to reasons attributable to (B), (B) cannot refuse to complete the counter-performance (i.e., making the payment). Therefore, (B) may not refuse the payment when (A) claims the payment from (B) on April 20.
attacking_argument: According to Article 536(2), since the bicycle was lost due to reasons attributable to (B), (B) cannot refuse to make the payment. However, the claim does not consider whether (A) still has an obligation to deliver the bicycle. If (P) was lost due to reasons attributable to (B), then it could be argued that (A)'s obligation to deliver the bicycle is also nullified, and thus (A) has no grounds to claim payment from (B) on April 20.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 670:
(1) The partnership business is decided by the majority of the partners and executed by each partner.
(2) The decision and execution of the partnership business may be delegated to one or more partners or a third party, pursuant to the provisions of the partnership contract.
(3) The person delegated as referred to in the preceding paragraph (hereinafter referred to as a "person who executes business") decides and executes the partnership business. In such a case, if there are two or more persons who execute business, the partnership business is decided by the majority of these persons who execute business and is executed by each of them.
(4) Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, the partnership business is not precluded to be decided based on the consent of all partners or executed by all partners.
(5) Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraphs, the ordinary business of a partnership may be performed by each partner or each person who executes business independently; provided, however, that this does not apply if other partners or persons who execute business raise objections prior to the completion of the business.
(Agency of Partnership)



        Conclusion:
        The partnership business is decided by the majority of the partners even if any person is delegated to be a person who executes business..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 670(1), the partnership business is decided by the majority of the partners. Even if delegation occurs as per Article 670(2) and Article 670(3), the decision-making process among those delegated (if more than one) still follows the majority rule, as stated in Article 670(3). Therefore, the partnership business is decided by the majority of the partners, whether directly or through a majority of delegated persons, ensuring the conclusion holds true.
attacking_argument: According to Article 670(3), if a partnership business is delegated to one or more persons who execute business, the decision-making authority for such business shifts to the majority of these delegated persons, not the majority of all partners. This directly contradicts the conclusion which incorrectly states that the partnership business is decided by the majority of the partners even when a person is delegated to be a person who executes business.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 296:
A holder of a right of retention may exercise that holder's rights against the whole of the thing retained until the relevant claim is satisfied in its entirety.
(Collection of Fruits by Holders of Rights of Retention)



        Conclusion:
        A holder of a right of retention may retain that thing until his/her claim is satisfied in its entirety..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 296, a holder of a right of retention may exercise their rights against the whole of the thing retained until the relevant claim is satisfied in its entirety. Therefore, the holder may retain the thing until the claim is fully satisfied, which directly supports the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion of the argument implies indefinite retention of the thing by the holder of the right of retention, which is not explicitly stated in Article 296. Article 296 only specifies that the holder may exercise their rights until the claim is satisfied, but does not specify the duration or conditions after the claim is satisfied.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 242:
The owner of immovables acquires ownership of a thing that has been attached thereto as its appurtenance; provided, however, that the rights of the other person that attached that thing by virtue of a title are not prejudiced.
(Accession to Movables)



        Conclusion:
        A has sown seed owned by A on land owned by B without title. If the seed grows to become a seedling, ownership of the seedling belongs to B..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 242, the owner of immovables acquires ownership of things attached to them as appurtenances if the rights of the person who attached those things are not prejudiced. Since the seed was attached to B's land without a title, B's ownership of the land includes the seedling, which is the natural growth of the seed. Thus, the ownership of the seedling belongs to B, as stated in the conclusion.
attacking_argument: According to Article 242, the owner of immovables acquires ownership of a thing that has been attached to the immovable property as an appurtenance only if the attachment is made by someone with a title or if the rights of the person who attached it are not prejudiced. In the scenario where A sowed seed owned by A on land owned by B without a title, the attachment of the seed was made without legal authority. However, the conclusion that the ownership of the seedling belongs to B assumes that the seedling is an appurtenance attached by A, which is not explicitly covered by Article 242 since the seed was originally A's property and sown without a title. Therefore, based on the specific wording of Article 242, the conclusion may not logically follow from the premises as presented, making the argument potentially invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 117:
(1) A person who concludes a contract as an agent of another person is liable to the counterparty for the performance of the contract or compensation for loss or damage, as chosen by the counterparty, unless the person proves the authority to represent or the principal ratifies the contract.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not apply in the following cases:
(i) if the counterparty knew that the person who concluded the contract as an agent of the other person had no authority to represent;
(ii) if the counterparty was negligent in not knowing that the person who concluded the contract as an agent of the other person had no authority to represent; provided, however, that this does not apply if the person who concluded a contract as an agent of the other person knew themselves to have no authority to represent; or
(iii) if the legal capacity to act of the person who concluded the contract as an agent of the other person was subject to restrictions.
(Unauthorized Agency in Unilateral Juridical Act)



        Conclusion:
        When An unauthorized agent acted believing that it had had authority of agency without negligence, it shall not be liable to the counterparty for the performance of the contract or damages even if it is unable to obtain the ratification of the principal..'''
supporting_argument: An unauthorized agent who acted without negligence and believed in their authority is not liable to the counterparty even if the principal does not ratify the contract, as stated in Article 117 (2)(ii), which relieves the agent of liability if the counterparty was negligent in not knowing about the lack of authority, and here the counterparty's negligence is negated by their lack of knowledge or negligence.
attacking_argument: The conclusion ignores the stipulation in Article 117(2)(ii) about the counterparty's negligence, which states that if the counterparty was negligent in not knowing that the agent had no authority, the agent remains liable. This directly contradicts the conclusion that an unauthorized agent who acted without negligence should not be liable, even if the principal does not ratify the contract.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 708:
A person that has paid money or delivered thing for an obligation for an illegal cause may not demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered; provided, however, that this does not apply if the illegal cause existed solely in relation to the Beneficiary.
Chapter V Torts
(Compensation for Loss or Damage in Torts)



        Conclusion:
        A person that has paid money or delivered thing for an obligation for an illegal cause may not demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered, even if the illegal cause existed solely in relation to the beneficiary..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 708, a person who pays money or delivers something for an illegal cause cannot demand the return of the money or item, and this rule applies even if the illegal cause was solely related to the beneficiary, thus directly supporting the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 708 by not acknowledging the exception clause that allows for the return of money or thing delivered if the illegal cause existed solely in relation to the beneficiary.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 439:
(1) If one of the joint and several obligors has a claim against the obligee and invokes a set-off, the claim is extinguished for the benefit of all joint and several obligors.
(2) Until the joint and several obligor that has the claim referred to in the preceding paragraph invokes a set-off, other joint and several obligors may refuse to perform the obligation to the obligee only to the extent of that joint and several obligor's share of the obligation.
(Merger with One of Joint and Several Obligors)



        Conclusion:
        If D owes C a debt (Y) of 300000 yen that is set off against the debt (X), and D demands payment of 600000 yen from A while C does not use a set-off for the debt (Y), A may refuse to pay 200000 yen of that debt..'''
supporting_argument: If D owes C a debt (Y) of 300000 yen that is set off against the debt (X), and C does not use a set-off for the debt (Y), according to Article 439 (2), other joint and several obligors (A) may refuse to perform the obligation to C only to the extent of D's share of the obligation, which is 200000 yen out of the 600000 yen D demands.
attacking_argument: According to Article 439(2), A may refuse to pay only up to the extent of C's share of the obligation, which is 300000 yen, not 200000 yen. Therefore, the conclusion that A may refuse to pay 200000 yen of the 600000 yen demanded by D does not logically follow from the premises, as A would only be justified in refusing to pay 300000 yen, not 200000 yen.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 11:
The family court may decide to commence a curatorship in respect of a person whose capacity to appreciate their own situation is extremely inadequate due to a mental disorder, at the request of the person in question, the person's spouse, the person's relative within the fourth degree of kinship, the guardian, the guardian's supervisor, the assistant, the assistant's supervisor, or a public prosecutor; provided, however, that this does not apply to a person in respect of whom a cause set forth in Article 7 exists.
(Persons under Curatorship; Curators)

Article 13:
(1) A person under curatorship must obtain the consent of the curator in order to perform any of the following acts; provided, however, that this does not apply to an act provided for in the proviso of Article 9:
(i) receiving or using any property producing civil fruit;
(ii) borrowing money or guaranteeing an obligation;
(iii) performing an act with the purpose of acquiring or losing any right regarding immovables or other significant property;
(iv) suing any procedural act;
(v) giving a gift, reaching a settlement, or entering into an arbitration agreement (meaning an arbitration agreement as provided in Article 2, paragraph (1) of the Arbitration Act (Act No. 138 of 2003));
(vi) accepting or renouncing a succession or dividing an estate;
(vii) refusing an offer of a gift, renouncing a legacy, accepting an offer of gift with burden, or accepting a legacy with burden;
(viii) constructing a new building, renovating, expanding, or undertaking major repairs;
(ix) granting a lease for a term that exceeds the period set forth in Article 602; or
(x) performing any of the acts set forth in the preceding items as a legal representative of a person with qualified legal capacity (meaning a minor, adult ward, or person under curatorship or a person under assistance who is subject to a decision as referred to in Article 17, paragraph (1); the same applies hereinafter).
(2) At the request of a person as referred to in the main clause of Article 11 or the curator or curator's supervisor, the family court may decide that the person under curatorship must also obtain the consent of the curator before performing an act other than those set forth in each of the items of the preceding paragraph; provided, however, that this does not apply to an act provided for in the proviso to Article 9.
(3) If the curator does not consent to an act for which the person under curatorship must obtain the curator's consent even though it is unlikely to prejudice the interests of the person under curatorship, the family court may grant permission that operates in lieu of the curator's consent at the request of the person under curatorship.
(4) An act for which the person under curatorship must obtain the curator's consent is voidable if the person performs it without obtaining the curator's consent or a permission that operates in lieu of it.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Curatorship)

Article 17:
(1) At the request of the person referred to in the main clause of Article 15, paragraph (1) or the assistant or assistant's supervisor, the family court may decide that the person under assistance must obtain the consent of the person's assistant in order to perform a specific juridical act; provided, however, that the acts that such a decision may establish as those for which the person must obtain the consent of the assistant are restricted to a part of the acts provided for in Article 13, paragraph (1).
(2) In order to decide as referred to in the preceding paragraph at the request of a person other than the person in question requires the consent of the person in question.
(3) If the assistant does not consent to an act for which the person under assistance must obtain the assistant's consent even though it is unlikely to prejudice the interests of the person under assistance, the family court may grant permission that operates in lieu of the assistant's consent, at the request of the person under assistance.
(4) An act for which the person under assistance must obtain the assistant's consent is voidable if the person performs it without obtaining the assistance's consent or a permission that operates in lieu of it.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Assistance)

Article 2:
This Code must be construed so as to honor the dignity of individuals and the essential equality of both sexes.
Chapter II Persons
Section 1 Capacity to Hold Rights

Article 602:
If a person with no authority of disposition makes a lease contract, the leases set forth in the following items must not exceed the terms specified in those items; any longer term specified by a contract is reduced to the term specified in the relevant item:
(i) leases of forest for the purpose of planting or felling trees: 10 years;
(ii) leases of land other than the leases set forth in the preceding item: five years;
(iii) lease of a building: three years; and
(iv) lease of movables: six months.
(Renewal of Short-Term Leases)

Article 9:
A juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable; provided, however, that this does not apply to the purchase of daily necessities or to any other act involved in day-to-day life.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Guardianship)



        Conclusion:
        With respect to any act which requires the consent of the curator, if the curator does not give consent in cases where the interest of the person under curatorship is unlikely to be prejudiced, the family court may, at the request of the person under curatorship, give permission in lieu of the consent of the curator..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 13, paragraph (3), if the curator does not consent to an act for which the person under curatorship must obtain the curator's consent even though it is unlikely to prejudice the interests of the person under curatorship, the family court may grant permission that operates in lieu of the curator's consent at the request of the person under curatorship. This directly supports the conclusion that the family court may give permission in lieu of the curator's consent when the curator does not consent to acts that are unlikely to prejudice the person's interests, making the argument's conclusion a logical consequence of its premise.
attacking_argument: The conclusion includes a broader interpretation of 'prejudice to interests' compared to the specific condition in Article 13, paragraph (3), which only refers to 'unlikely to prejudice the interests'. This introduces an ambiguity that was not present in the original statute and therefore does not logically entail the conclusion as stated.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 254:
A claim that one of the co-owners holds against other co-owners with respect to the property in co-ownership may be exercised against their specific successors.
(Waiver of Interests and Death of Co-Owners)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where person A pays in advance management fees for a building co-owned by person A and person B, and person C receives  the share from person B, person A can demand that person C should  pay for person A's payments..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 254, person A can exercise any claims against person B's share to person C, who is now the successor of person B. Since person A has paid management fees in advance for the co-owned building, this constitutes a claim against person B. Hence, as person C is the specific successor, person A can demand that person C should pay for the management fees paid by person A.
attacking_argument: Paying advance management fees is a financial obligation and does not qualify as a claim 'with respect to the property in co-ownership' as specified in Article 254. Therefore, person A cannot logically demand that person C should pay for person A's payments based solely on the information provided in Article 254.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of statute articles
        along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 676:
(1) If a partner has disposed of the interest of the partner with respect to the partnership property, that partner may not duly assert that disposition against the partnership or third parties that had dealings with the partnership.
